00:21:56.260 --> 00:21:57.070
>> Okay.
>> For the most part,

391
00:21:57.070 --> 00:21:58.768
I just leave open but you can do that.

392
00:21:58.768 --> 00:22:00.740
>> Okay, very good.

393
00:22:00.740 --> 00:22:01.520
All right.

394
00:22:01.520 --> 00:22:02.350
Well, I tell you what, Felicia.

395
00:22:02.350 --> 00:22:05.550
It was a great look there at setting
up that company information.

396
00:22:05.550 --> 00:22:08.280
You know, that organization info,
the company profile.

397
00:22:08.280 --> 00:22:10.820
A lot of this is done when
you're first setting it up.

398
00:22:10.820 --> 00:22:13.900
But it's great to know how we can
get back in there and make changes.

399
00:22:13.900 --> 00:22:16.990
As my organization grows,
or make changes to that.

400
00:22:16.990 --> 00:22:18.300
So we appreciate that.

401
00:22:18.300 --> 00:22:20.420
We hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

402
00:22:20.420 --> 00:22:22.785
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

403
00:22:22.785 --> 00:22:23.712
>> I'm Felicia Duarte.

404
00:22:23.712 --> 00:22:26.360
>> And we'll see you next time.

405
00:22:26.360 --> 00:22:32.305
[MUSIC]

406
00:22:32.305 --> 00:22:36.930
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Felicia and Mike demonstrate setting up users in Salesforce. They also cover the options for controlling user access.
episodes.title: User Setup and Security Access
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.490
Welcome to IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.490 --> 00:00:06.281
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.281 --> 00:00:08.281
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.281 --> 00:00:12.650
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:12.650 --> 00:00:15.700
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:15.700 --> 00:00:17.950
I'm you're host Mike Rodrick and

7
00:00:17.950 --> 00:00:21.400
today we're doing our Salesforce
certified administrator.

8
00:00:21.400 --> 00:00:26.820
And in this episode we're gonna be taking
a look, a user setup and security access.

9
00:00:26.820 --> 00:00:30.160
And here to help us with
that is Miss Felicia Duarte.

10
00:00:30.160 --> 00:00:31.500
Welcome back Felicia.

11
00:00:31.500 --> 00:00:32.500
>> Thank you.

12
00:00:32.500 --> 00:00:36.760
So this portion here covers 9%
of the Salesforce questions.

13
00:00:36.760 --> 00:00:38.372
So it's pretty hefty.

14
00:00:38.372 --> 00:00:42.060
You wanna brush up on things you
aren't aware of in this section here.

15
00:00:42.060 --> 00:00:48.520
So this covers common occurrences of
the Salesforce admin will set up so

16
00:00:48.520 --> 00:00:53.690
that setting up users,
creating users, disabling users,

17
00:00:53.690 --> 00:00:56.040
and having make a changes
to email profiles.

18
00:00:56.040 --> 00:01:01.330
So it's pretty straightforward and simple,
but something that you do work on and

19
00:01:01.330 --> 00:01:04.450
it's a common occurrences that
happens as a Salesforce admin.

20
00:01:04.450 --> 00:01:09.240
So I'm gonna start with the basics here
and show you how to create a user.

21
00:01:09.240 --> 00:01:12.740
Some of the options you have available,
and just kinda go through some of

22
00:01:12.740 --> 00:01:17.220
the issues with troubleshooting user,
most common issues and scenarios.

23
00:01:17.220 --> 00:01:23.590
So let's just start here at my homepage,
and go back to the setup.

24
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:27.640
And this is where you'll live most
of the time as a system admin,

25
00:01:27.640 --> 00:01:29.330
in the setup section.

26
00:01:29.330 --> 00:01:36.230
So as I scroll down, I'm gonna select
Manage Users, and go to Users.

27
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:43.160
So at this user home page here, right now
we're looking at the developer org and

28
00:01:43.160 --> 00:01:47.010
so you're only gonna see the one that
Salesforce give you out the box which is

29
00:01:47.010 --> 00:01:48.790
the chatter expert user.

30
00:01:48.790 --> 00:01:50.750
The one that I created which is myself and

31
00:01:50.750 --> 00:01:54.210
a couple other users that Salesforce
gives you to kind of play around with.

32
00:01:54.210 --> 00:01:58.160
But when you're dealing with
an organization that has 100 users or

33
00:01:58.160 --> 00:01:59.370
even more than a 120.

34
00:01:59.370 --> 00:02:03.556
Wanna be able to split up, and
segment the way you see this data and

35
00:02:03.556 --> 00:02:04.860
this information.

36
00:02:04.860 --> 00:02:08.608
So, right you have here,
at top is called your list view.

37
00:02:08.608 --> 00:02:11.720
Right now we're look in a view of
all users, but may be we wanna,

38
00:02:11.720 --> 00:02:18.610
split it up to active or inactive users or
by territory and region.

39
00:02:18.610 --> 00:02:20.830
So, you would just Create a New View for
that.

40
00:02:20.830 --> 00:02:25.200
Salesforce off the box will give
you the views of Active Users,

41
00:02:25.200 --> 00:02:29.490
Admin Users, and
right now the default being All Users.

42
00:02:29.490 --> 00:02:36.380
But if I select Create New View,
Let's use the task of Inactive Users.

43
00:02:38.480 --> 00:02:42.080
And all throughout Salesforce,
as I select the view name,

44
00:02:42.080 --> 00:02:44.870
if I hit tab it will automatically
always create that API name.

45
00:02:44.870 --> 00:02:49.070
Just something to be aware of,
as you're working through this.

46
00:02:49.070 --> 00:02:53.700
So maybe I wanna be able to filter
out by the status of this user.

47
00:02:53.700 --> 00:02:55.990
These are all your fields
available to the user.

48
00:02:55.990 --> 00:02:59.820
So in a user account,
you can create custom fields.

49
00:02:59.820 --> 00:03:02.780
Just like you can any
standard Salesforce object.

50
00:03:02.780 --> 00:03:08.123
So right now we're just going to do
the basics status or let's see here,

51
00:03:11.620 --> 00:03:14.280
So let's use the example
of State right here.

52
00:03:14.280 --> 00:03:17.660
I see it right here, so state equals and

53
00:03:17.660 --> 00:03:21.460
maybe I'm segmenting my users by region or
territory.

54
00:03:21.460 --> 00:03:24.020
But I just wanna give you
examples of what you can do,

55
00:03:24.020 --> 00:03:27.120
what's in your operators
are within Salesforce.

56
00:03:27.120 --> 00:03:30.049
So equal to being the exact,
then not equal to and

57
00:03:31.300 --> 00:03:34.510
all of those operator
values that we have here.

58
00:03:34.510 --> 00:03:38.800
So, I would just to enter the abbreviated
form or the spelled out form.

59
00:03:38.800 --> 00:03:43.290
You can kinda catches what
criteria you can set here.

60
00:03:43.290 --> 00:03:44.870
And what field do you want to display?

61
00:03:44.870 --> 00:03:47.730
What information to be
importance to see at a glance

62
00:03:47.730 --> 00:03:50.310
when you're looking through
this different views.

63
00:03:50.310 --> 00:03:54.310
And who has visibility to see
the view that you created.

64
00:03:54.310 --> 00:03:55.530
Is this something personal just for

65
00:03:55.530 --> 00:03:59.150
you to kind of quickly navigate as
you're working through the org.

66
00:03:59.150 --> 00:04:04.120
Or is this something you want any other
user who has access to this area to see.

67
00:04:04.120 --> 00:04:07.420
So that was just kind of
an example to show you list views.

68
00:04:07.420 --> 00:04:10.240
And you'll see this all
throughout Salesforce.

69
00:04:10.240 --> 00:04:12.980
We'll go more in depth as
into the different operators,

70
00:04:12.980 --> 00:04:17.400
but that's the place to segment
your different users here.

71
00:04:17.400 --> 00:04:20.580
>> That's fantastic, and as that list
gets longer and longer and longer,

72
00:04:20.580 --> 00:04:24.470
and having to filter it down
every time I go in there.

73
00:04:24.470 --> 00:04:28.560
The ability to save those filters, so that
I can quickly see just what I need to see.

74
00:04:28.560 --> 00:04:29.700
>> Exactly right.

75
00:04:29.700 --> 00:04:31.770
And has the system admin easier,
the better.

76
00:04:31.770 --> 00:04:34.930
The quicker way, fastest way to get there,
you have to go over here.

77
00:04:34.930 --> 00:04:37.350
[LAUGH] So I'm gonna go into my user.

78
00:04:39.760 --> 00:04:44.400
Right now first to show up you just
the fields available, what you can see,

79
00:04:44.400 --> 00:04:49.150
what you can make changes to,
what is the user detail page look like.

80
00:04:49.150 --> 00:04:51.340
So right here we have
basic contact information.

81
00:04:51.340 --> 00:04:53.270
We have my email, user name.

82
00:04:54.310 --> 00:04:55.670
Salesforce requires a nickname.

83
00:04:55.670 --> 00:04:57.680
And some of these fields are required.

84
00:04:57.680 --> 00:05:03.330
So as we went over through in the last
episode with OrgY, you also have new user.

85
00:05:03.330 --> 00:05:08.250
So you have a personal address and
title related here.

86
00:05:08.250 --> 00:05:11.780
This is where you make those changes for
each individual user.

87
00:05:14.100 --> 00:05:19.750
So as we scroll through here, is this user
have approval, is it a delegated approval?

88
00:05:19.750 --> 00:05:22.350
Does it have responsibilities
to be an improver?

89
00:05:22.350 --> 00:05:26.620
What is it's role here, and this is
where most of that information sits.

90
00:05:26.620 --> 00:05:28.980
And this is where you would
go to make those changes.

91
00:05:30.160 --> 00:05:35.050
Before I go that, let's go into
the creation of creating the new user.

92
00:05:37.120 --> 00:05:39.306
So I'm going to hit New User,

93
00:05:39.306 --> 00:05:44.040
if I'm going to add an individual
new user 1% percent of time.

94
00:05:44.040 --> 00:05:46.220
But if you're up and running and

95
00:05:46.220 --> 00:05:49.410
you need to add 10 users at a time
it's faster just to create.

96
00:05:49.410 --> 00:05:51.410
And sometimes this is often missed.

97
00:05:51.410 --> 00:05:54.090
Add multiple users,
it just makes things easier,

98
00:05:54.090 --> 00:05:58.330
it makes this sort of
tedious process less tedious.

99
00:05:58.330 --> 00:06:02.190
If you're gonna assign them all
the same profile or license.

100
00:06:02.190 --> 00:06:05.610
So if I was assigning everyone
a Salesforce license,

101
00:06:05.610 --> 00:06:11.490
you'll see here that as I select
license itself, it wouldn't say.

102
00:06:11.490 --> 00:06:17.380
Select is gonna now give me the option to
multi create many different licenses and

103
00:06:17.380 --> 00:06:19.539
users, I'm sorry,
many different users here.

104
00:06:20.960 --> 00:06:24.760
So just giving you that option here,
which is nice to have.

105
00:06:25.970 --> 00:06:28.972
So I'm gonna navigate back here and
just do one.

106
00:06:33.558 --> 00:06:37.210
Kinda hopping around here, and
go back into the tiles and

107
00:06:37.210 --> 00:06:40.620
fields that you have available for a user.

108
00:06:40.620 --> 00:06:43.870
So going back to as part
of different licenses.

109
00:06:43.870 --> 00:06:46.420
If you had licenses to some
of those future licenses and

110
00:06:46.420 --> 00:06:50.500
you wanna add it to user,
you'll see in a place a check box here.

111
00:06:50.500 --> 00:06:55.450
So if you wanna make this a work.com user,
if that license was available,

112
00:06:55.450 --> 00:06:57.950
you would go into this section here and
check it.

113
00:06:57.950 --> 00:07:01.430
And now they have access once you save it.

114
00:07:01.430 --> 00:07:04.590
So going through, these are just all
your different options that you can make

115
00:07:04.590 --> 00:07:06.940
changes to, is this a Salesforce one user?

116
00:07:06.940 --> 00:07:09.230
Do you wanna remove that privilege?

117
00:07:09.230 --> 00:07:14.200
This is something often heard if
you want to not allowed anyone

118
00:07:14.200 --> 00:07:17.860
to use Salesforce one app, this where
you need to go in and make the changes.

119
00:07:17.860 --> 00:07:21.170
Across the board,
via profiles and user itself.

120
00:07:21.170 --> 00:07:26.080
So, you can see this pretty all
straightforward make change to the default

121
00:07:26.080 --> 00:07:31.968
landing page, having access to
the force.com quick access menu.

122
00:07:31.968 --> 00:07:37.410
So these here, again this is per user and
in future episodes,

123
00:07:37.410 --> 00:07:43.270
we're gonna go through grouping
these users and profiles as a whole.

124
00:07:43.270 --> 00:07:47.400
Let's tackle back into here as we see
the Start of Day, and End of Day,

125
00:07:47.400 --> 00:07:51.477
and Used Data Space and File Space,
let's tackle back up into here,

126
00:07:58.728 --> 00:08:00.283
Sorry, lost my place here.

127
00:08:00.283 --> 00:08:03.082
[LAUGH] As far as the business
hours go for the user.

128
00:08:03.082 --> 00:08:06.354
So this is not start of day and
end of day,

129
00:08:06.354 --> 00:08:10.878
it does not just give them
restriction as far as when they

130
00:08:10.878 --> 00:08:15.616
can log in if they were to log
in during a different period.

131
00:08:15.616 --> 00:08:18.179
That's all related to support hours again,
so

132
00:08:18.179 --> 00:08:20.429
back to what we were discussing earlier.

133
00:08:20.429 --> 00:08:29.843
But let me navigate over to,
Common occurences.

134
00:08:29.843 --> 00:08:33.696
So as I'm here, being a system admin,
it's very straight forward and

135
00:08:33.696 --> 00:08:34.928
easy to create a user.

136
00:08:34.928 --> 00:08:39.770
So there are some required fields
when you're creating a new user.

137
00:08:39.770 --> 00:08:44.320
And as I do so here, you're gonna
see those fields highlighted in red.

138
00:08:44.320 --> 00:08:48.330
So I can have, as long as I have
a last name, I can create a user.

139
00:08:48.330 --> 00:08:52.310
So I'm going to type through here, but
as you select the tab, some of these

140
00:08:52.310 --> 00:08:58.190
are going to pre-fill for you, like the
alias, you have to have an email address.

141
00:08:58.190 --> 00:09:00.650
And then your username has to be unique.

142
00:09:00.650 --> 00:09:05.411
So I can with my developer org, use my
work email in multiple different orgs,

143
00:09:05.411 --> 00:09:06.375
that's okay.

144
00:09:06.375 --> 00:09:09.835
But your username has to be unique.

145
00:09:09.835 --> 00:09:11.792
So keep that in mind too.

146
00:09:11.792 --> 00:09:15.890
And then as you go through this,
so if I were just to enter a few,

147
00:09:15.890 --> 00:09:20.260
you see that's a nickname,
also gets auto created for you.

148
00:09:20.260 --> 00:09:23.185
So, everything else here
that's not highlighted in red,

149
00:09:23.185 --> 00:09:26.457
sure as you know as a system admin,
it's not a required to field but

150
00:09:26.457 --> 00:09:29.577
you cannot save the record unless
those fields are filled out.

151
00:09:29.577 --> 00:09:34.070
With the exception of
the Role field right here.

152
00:09:34.070 --> 00:09:37.030
So for this one right here,
it's highlighted in red.

153
00:09:37.030 --> 00:09:38.150
But for the most part,

154
00:09:38.150 --> 00:09:41.510
you do not have to select a role
in order to save this record.

155
00:09:41.510 --> 00:09:45.660
So everything else you select
the license that you wanna assign.

156
00:09:45.660 --> 00:09:48.250
So as we went through
those different licenses,

157
00:09:48.250 --> 00:09:49.830
is it a standard Salesforce license?

158
00:09:49.830 --> 00:09:52.500
Is it a Force.com license?

159
00:09:52.500 --> 00:09:54.970
Any licenses that you have
available will show here.

160
00:09:54.970 --> 00:09:59.390
So it's not gonna show a license that
you haven't purchased or have access to.

161
00:09:59.390 --> 00:10:03.740
And then this is also another way if
you've used up all those licenses,

162
00:10:03.740 --> 00:10:06.230
then a Salesforce license
isn't gonna show.

163
00:10:06.230 --> 00:10:09.215
So this is also your way to fill out hey,
I'm out of licenses.

164
00:10:09.215 --> 00:10:11.492
[LAUGH] As you're creating the users and

165
00:10:11.492 --> 00:10:14.327
sometimes you know system
admin will get stuck.

166
00:10:14.327 --> 00:10:18.280
So that's your way of knowing hey,
I need to purchase more.

167
00:10:18.280 --> 00:10:23.430
And then profiles which we'll get into,
every user has to have one profile.

168
00:10:23.430 --> 00:10:25.440
So, right now I am a system admin.

169
00:10:25.440 --> 00:10:31.630
I have a system admin profile which gives
me access to read, edit, modify all.

170
00:10:31.630 --> 00:10:36.140
So, if I were to select marketing user,
offline users, if I had access,

171
00:10:36.140 --> 00:10:37.540
I can make these changes there.

172
00:10:38.700 --> 00:10:39.710
And as we scroll through,

173
00:10:41.370 --> 00:10:44.100
these are some of the changes you
can make which we went through.

174
00:10:44.100 --> 00:10:48.310
But for this example, I don't need
to add anything if I wanted to add

175
00:10:48.310 --> 00:10:52.770
maybe a call center that we have
conducted in the phone line there,

176
00:10:52.770 --> 00:10:55.166
the phone,
all of that can be set up right here.

177
00:10:55.166 --> 00:11:02.410
And let's scroll through, once

178
00:11:02.410 --> 00:11:07.700
you create a user, so you have the option
of giving that user access right away.

179
00:11:07.700 --> 00:11:11.690
From an implementation standpoint,
sometimes we're not ready yet

180
00:11:11.690 --> 00:11:13.600
to give out those passwords.

181
00:11:13.600 --> 00:11:17.031
Sometimes we're just getting the user
setup because we need to be able to map

182
00:11:17.031 --> 00:11:19.081
them to other things and
to historical data.

183
00:11:19.081 --> 00:11:23.412
But by default,
this part here is checked off.

184
00:11:23.412 --> 00:11:28.387
So if I were to hit save or
maybe I'm going through these too fast,

185
00:11:28.387 --> 00:11:34.020
these users would get a notification
with a link to log in to Salesforce.

186
00:11:34.020 --> 00:11:35.200
>> So even if you're not ready for it,

187
00:11:35.200 --> 00:11:37.012
they might be trying to
log in to your system?

188
00:11:37.012 --> 00:11:39.690
>> Right, so watch out,
it's at the very end.

189
00:11:39.690 --> 00:11:42.288
I know sometimes you're kind of
running through these in creating it.

190
00:11:42.288 --> 00:11:45.220
But look at out here and
then just deselect.

191
00:11:46.620 --> 00:11:51.820
And that's great to just get your user set
up, and not have to generate passwords or

192
00:11:51.820 --> 00:11:55.830
give them information,
give them an access, just yet.

193
00:11:55.830 --> 00:11:58.530
>> Now does that still generate a password
and just not send it to them or

194
00:11:58.530 --> 00:12:01.450
now do we have to some how reset or
create a password?

195
00:12:01.450 --> 00:12:02.380
>> Yeah, great question.

196
00:12:02.380 --> 00:12:05.210
So at the point,
let's say you didn't select that and

197
00:12:05.210 --> 00:12:09.520
you saved maybe 10 different users and
now you've hit the point where you wanna

198
00:12:09.520 --> 00:12:12.820
assign passwords out,
it's really a simple task.

199
00:12:12.820 --> 00:12:18.870
I'm back at my home page of my users, so
I would just select the users if not all

200
00:12:20.010 --> 00:12:26.710
or one by one maybe these two users here,
I need to send them a password.

201
00:12:26.710 --> 00:12:28.540
I would just hit Reset Password,

202
00:12:28.540 --> 00:12:32.840
and this also covers the topic
of resetting password.

203
00:12:32.840 --> 00:12:34.920
So, once I hit Reset Password,

204
00:12:34.920 --> 00:12:39.360
it's gonna send them an email to
the email field that we had there.

205
00:12:41.060 --> 00:12:45.840
And so, that can be used across as your
users, or maybe they're trying to log in

206
00:12:45.840 --> 00:12:50.300
and they froze out their accounts,
there's only so many attempts that

207
00:12:50.300 --> 00:12:55.040
you can make before having to hit reset
my password before they're frozen.

208
00:12:55.040 --> 00:12:57.650
And at that point,
when they froze out their accounts,

209
00:12:57.650 --> 00:12:59.710
they're gonna have to reach out to you,
and you're the only person,

210
00:12:59.710 --> 00:13:04.060
as system admin, that has rights
to make those changes here.

211
00:13:04.060 --> 00:13:09.260
And sometimes I suggest as best practice,
you wanna have at least maybe two system

212
00:13:09.260 --> 00:13:12.690
admins even if it's a smaller
size employee account.

213
00:13:12.690 --> 00:13:16.730
Because if one thing goes wrong for one
system admin it's pretty tough to kind of

214
00:13:16.730 --> 00:13:20.170
have to get in there without
a system admin having access.

215
00:13:20.170 --> 00:13:23.660
So that's your place
to make changes there.

216
00:13:23.660 --> 00:13:27.910
A common issue that comes across besides

217
00:13:29.150 --> 00:13:32.760
user changes would be the changes
to the email address.

218
00:13:32.760 --> 00:13:35.670
So what do you do if you need to
change an email address at that point?

219
00:13:35.670 --> 00:13:36.400
Where does that go?

220
00:13:36.400 --> 00:13:37.530
Who does that go to?

221
00:13:37.530 --> 00:13:40.848
It's real simple as far as
changing the email itself.

222
00:13:40.848 --> 00:13:45.384
But it's good to know that if I
needed to change my email, here,

223
00:13:45.384 --> 00:13:51.264
it's not gonna show me, if I were to edit
and change it to a different address here,

224
00:13:51.264 --> 00:13:55.884
it's not gonna change the email
address yet until it will send out

225
00:13:55.884 --> 00:14:00.601
an email to the changed email address,
until you select the link.

226
00:14:00.601 --> 00:14:03.905
>> Kinda verifying that that is the actual
valid email that you wanna use.

227
00:14:03.905 --> 00:14:06.960
>> Right, yes, so until that point
it's gonna stay as the original.

228
00:14:06.960 --> 00:14:09.580
>> I see, very good.

229
00:14:09.580 --> 00:14:15.700
Now what about if we have people
that leave the organization.

230
00:14:15.700 --> 00:14:17.375
How do we deal with those user accounts?

231
00:14:17.375 --> 00:14:23.640
>> Great, so it is good to know that you
can not ever delete a user for historical

232
00:14:23.640 --> 00:14:28.240
purposes but you can deactivate a user,
and that is what you would want to do.

233
00:14:28.240 --> 00:14:33.430
There are a few things you do wanna
keep into consideration about the user,

234
00:14:33.430 --> 00:14:39.300
so if we go into the user itself, you can
see whether my role is active or inactive.

235
00:14:39.300 --> 00:14:46.200
And then you'll have the option to
change whether I'm active or inactive.

236
00:14:48.570 --> 00:14:51.240
Once you do so, that opens up and
frees up the license.

237
00:14:51.240 --> 00:14:53.450
And then there's a few things to consider.

238
00:14:53.450 --> 00:14:55.500
So, once deactivated,

239
00:14:55.500 --> 00:15:00.760
the user immediately loses accessibility
if it was a part of a sharing role.

240
00:15:00.760 --> 00:15:04.660
So, you wanna keep that in mind as
you're deactivating those users.

241
00:15:04.660 --> 00:15:09.840
So, any sharing records
are lost once you do so.

242
00:15:09.840 --> 00:15:13.113
You also can be deactivated if you are,
let's say for

243
00:15:13.113 --> 00:15:16.700
a costumer portal,
if you're the administrator there.

244
00:15:16.700 --> 00:15:19.429
So, you need to go in and
make those changes.

245
00:15:19.429 --> 00:15:25.330
Same to email alerts as far as
who the user is at that point.

246
00:15:25.330 --> 00:15:27.548
And then, you can go in and
deactivate a user.

247
00:15:27.548 --> 00:15:31.772
So it's kind of little bit of
digging that you have to do before

248
00:15:31.772 --> 00:15:33.650
deactivating some users.

249
00:15:33.650 --> 00:15:38.010
And they will notify you if they're
related to anything that can

250
00:15:38.010 --> 00:15:41.410
cause changes before doing so,
within Salesforce.

251
00:15:41.410 --> 00:15:43.275
>> And another thing I meant to ask you,
Felicia,

252
00:15:43.275 --> 00:15:46.390
was the when they get sent that email
it will say we create some new users.

253
00:15:46.390 --> 00:15:49.820
They're gonna get this notification
with this password that's generated.

254
00:15:49.820 --> 00:15:52.026
Is there a timeframe when they
have to work with that or

255
00:15:52.026 --> 00:15:54.350
I'm gonna have email sit in my inbox for
a while.

256
00:15:54.350 --> 00:15:55.547
Maybe I'm not ready to
log in at Salesforce.

257
00:15:55.547 --> 00:15:57.669
>> Yeah, you have within 24 hours.

258
00:15:57.669 --> 00:15:58.299
>> Okay.

259
00:15:58.299 --> 00:16:01.074
>> Yep, so before having to go in
there and kinda doing it again.

260
00:16:01.074 --> 00:16:03.546
So that's good to know.

261
00:16:03.546 --> 00:16:07.547
Another thing that I do
wanna cover is IP login and

262
00:16:07.547 --> 00:16:12.830
restrictions, login access,
login hours, and time frames.

263
00:16:12.830 --> 00:16:16.160
So there are login hours that
I've kinda gone through that

264
00:16:16.160 --> 00:16:18.950
will allow you to only allow users to

265
00:16:18.950 --> 00:16:22.500
be available to access Salesforce
within a certain amount of time.

266
00:16:22.500 --> 00:16:28.800
So you can set that up, and let's go
over here to the Login Access Policies.

267
00:16:28.800 --> 00:16:30.821
And this falls under Security Controls.

268
00:16:35.696 --> 00:16:39.689
So this part here will just go over
as far as support information can go,

269
00:16:39.689 --> 00:16:41.520
where that information sits.

270
00:16:41.520 --> 00:16:47.720
But let me go over into, Network Access.

271
00:16:47.720 --> 00:16:52.124
And this information here,
if I wanna keep track of a, first,

272
00:16:52.124 --> 00:16:53.877
a range of IP addresses.

273
00:16:53.877 --> 00:16:56.520
So maybe within the org that I'm in,

274
00:16:56.520 --> 00:17:01.340
I wanna keep track of those range
of APIs only accessible to login.

275
00:17:01.340 --> 00:17:04.172
This is where you select and
create those ranges here.

276
00:17:04.172 --> 00:17:09.640
If it's just an individual user, you just
use the same start and end IP address.

277
00:17:11.010 --> 00:17:13.689
Best practice tip too is,
it's not required, but

278
00:17:13.689 --> 00:17:18.115
add a description cuz as you're going
through and adding multiple, multiple, and

279
00:17:18.115 --> 00:17:19.938
there's some you want to remove.

280
00:17:19.938 --> 00:17:25.860
It's hard to keep track if you're not able
to distinguish whose IP belongs to who.

281
00:17:25.860 --> 00:17:26.733
But with that, [CROSSTALK] go ahead.

282
00:17:26.733 --> 00:17:29.845
>> As I was gonna say that's a great
security feature there cuz I know a lot of

283
00:17:29.845 --> 00:17:31.733
times we'll have company assigned, say,

284
00:17:31.733 --> 00:17:35.118
laptop that has all the appropriate
software protection, things like that.

285
00:17:35.118 --> 00:17:38.620
And I want my users to be able to login
but not maybe from their home computer,

286
00:17:38.620 --> 00:17:40.043
which is not under my control,

287
00:17:40.043 --> 00:17:43.960
which I don't know what keystroke loggers
are running on it, and things like that.

288
00:17:43.960 --> 00:17:47.501
So being able to say you can access it,
but only from this IP address,

289
00:17:47.501 --> 00:17:48.614
that's fantastic.

290
00:17:48.614 --> 00:17:50.470
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] yeah, and
then so you have control.

291
00:17:50.470 --> 00:17:54.160
So I'm gonna go back into
this Manage Users section.

292
00:17:54.160 --> 00:17:56.380
So as you saw, sometimes with Salesforce,

293
00:17:56.380 --> 00:17:59.380
there's a few keywords that I
remember as far as how to navigate.

294
00:17:59.380 --> 00:18:00.840
So I'm just typing in user.

295
00:18:00.840 --> 00:18:05.850
And it's gonna pull me into the areas that
I'm looking to to navigate and go to.

296
00:18:05.850 --> 00:18:09.677
So I'm gonna go into
right now Login History.

297
00:18:12.280 --> 00:18:16.217
So again, for the same reason
of why you can't delete a user,

298
00:18:16.217 --> 00:18:19.339
you want this information for
accountability.

299
00:18:19.339 --> 00:18:24.664
As a system admin maybe someone had access
to make a change to the org as a whole and

300
00:18:24.664 --> 00:18:27.565
that affected something, who made that.

301
00:18:27.565 --> 00:18:30.438
You always have the created by and
last modified by.

302
00:18:30.438 --> 00:18:35.326
But this is your audit trail
between kind of what was done

303
00:18:35.326 --> 00:18:38.870
setup wise in Salesforce and who did it.

304
00:18:38.870 --> 00:18:41.840
So you can use this and
you can generate a CSV file.

305
00:18:43.050 --> 00:18:45.650
I'm sorry,
this is just on the Login History.

306
00:18:45.650 --> 00:18:47.660
And have this generate CSV file and

307
00:18:47.660 --> 00:18:50.517
be able to report on it or
pull in as far as logins go.

308
00:18:53.330 --> 00:18:58.020
And what I was speaking to,
I got tongue tied, was set up audit trail.

309
00:18:58.020 --> 00:19:02.740
So if I hit setup, this is more or
less what I was first

310
00:19:02.740 --> 00:19:07.010
referring to as far as who did what,
when did they do it as far as setup goes.

311
00:19:07.010 --> 00:19:11.410
So this can also be pulled
out into a CSV file as well.

312
00:19:11.410 --> 00:19:15.305
So we have Manage Users, and
I like to pull this out and

313
00:19:15.305 --> 00:19:21.119
be able to filter out sometimes when
things were made, when changes were made.

314
00:19:21.119 --> 00:19:23.205
Or I need to go in as a system admin and

315
00:19:23.205 --> 00:19:28.470
kind of clean up work that someone else
did, where do I start, where do I look?

316
00:19:28.470 --> 00:19:33.460
This audit trail really helps me kind of
see what kind of work was done within

317
00:19:33.460 --> 00:19:40.090
the last, I think it gives you up to
60 days of work, I'm sorry, 6 months.

318
00:19:40.090 --> 00:19:44.296
Right now, we're in a developer org so
it's not gonna give you that many but

319
00:19:44.296 --> 00:19:47.532
you have up to 6 months to be
able to pull it into a CSV file.

320
00:19:49.680 --> 00:19:57.665
So as I go through this,
let's go through, Back into the users,

321
00:20:01.945 --> 00:20:04.770
And the Identification
Verification History here.

322
00:20:06.690 --> 00:20:11.390
So this will show you and display any
verification attempts that were made.

323
00:20:11.390 --> 00:20:13.290
If maybe you're having
issues with a user and

324
00:20:13.290 --> 00:20:15.840
there's multiple attempts
being made from different IPs.

325
00:20:15.840 --> 00:20:17.630
Is there something that
you need to look into?

326
00:20:17.630 --> 00:20:21.690
Do you need to change some of
the settings and password settings there?

327
00:20:21.690 --> 00:20:24.760
This is just kind of the place to see in.

328
00:20:24.760 --> 00:20:27.447
Right now, we don't have any,
it's a new developer org but

329
00:20:27.447 --> 00:20:29.514
it's good to know
the verification history.

330
00:20:29.514 --> 00:20:34.226
If they receive the email, what kind
of issues and troubleshoot is going

331
00:20:34.226 --> 00:20:38.410
on with getting a user kind of reset and
logged into Salesforce.

332
00:20:40.970 --> 00:20:45.510
And then, one of the last things that I
want to go over is the checkout access.

333
00:20:45.510 --> 00:20:50.086
So, as I kind of referred to as
the beginning, if you do need to

334
00:20:50.086 --> 00:20:55.278
purchase more data, more licenses,
a new feature with Salesforce,

335
00:20:55.278 --> 00:20:59.683
you can always reach out to
Salesforce Account executive.

336
00:20:59.683 --> 00:21:03.100
But Salesforce also has a checkout option.

337
00:21:03.100 --> 00:21:08.059
And you'll see it as a check box within
your user account and it will say

338
00:21:08.059 --> 00:21:13.538
checkout enabled within those lists of
settings that we originally went to.

339
00:21:13.538 --> 00:21:19.058
And if you scroll to the bottom,
as a developer org, I will not see it.

340
00:21:19.058 --> 00:21:22.650
You'll see in option at the very
bottom that will say checkout.

341
00:21:22.650 --> 00:21:27.729
Navigating to this link here will take you
through all your accounting information,

342
00:21:27.729 --> 00:21:30.138
billing information with Salesforce.

343
00:21:30.138 --> 00:21:31.970
Are you up to date with your billing?

344
00:21:31.970 --> 00:21:34.225
Who is your Salesforce account executive?

345
00:21:34.225 --> 00:21:38.193
It'll take over to purchasing
new licenses or new add-ons,

346
00:21:38.193 --> 00:21:43.330
in case you don't wanna have to go through
your Salesforce account executive.

347
00:21:43.330 --> 00:21:47.248
You can just directly purchase and
check out from Salesforce.

348
00:21:47.248 --> 00:21:48.057
>> Very convenient, all right.

349
00:21:48.057 --> 00:21:53.800
Well, again, another great look
being able to set up our users.

350
00:21:53.800 --> 00:21:57.846
Working with creating their accounts,
giving them the appropriate level of

351
00:21:57.846 --> 00:22:01.844
access, setting their password,
resetting their password if we need to.

352
00:22:01.844 --> 00:22:02.693
Where we can go and

353
00:22:02.693 --> 00:22:06.210
even purchase licenses without having
to contact Salesforce directly.

354
00:22:06.210 --> 00:22:07.830
So we appreciate that Felicia,

355
00:22:07.830 --> 00:22:10.390
we hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

356
00:22:10.390 --> 00:22:13.590
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Roderick.

357
00:22:13.590 --> 00:22:14.710
>> I'm Felicia Duarte.

358
00:22:14.710 --> 00:22:15.561
>> And we'll see you next time

359
00:22:15.561 --> 00:22:22.986
[MUSIC]

360
00:22:22.986 --> 00:22:25.010
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Felicia and Mike demonstrate configuring the Global User Interface in Salesforce. They go over various options that can be configured globally by the Salesforce admin within Classic Salesforce.
episodes.title: Global User Interface
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.912
Welcome to IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Don Pizzet.

2
00:00:02.912 --> 00:00:07.185
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.185 --> 00:00:08.815
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.815 --> 00:00:12.417
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:12.417 --> 00:00:15.590
>> Hello welcome to another
exciting episode here at IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:15.590 --> 00:00:17.640
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and

7
00:00:17.640 --> 00:00:20.786
today we're doing our
Salesforce Certified Administrator.

8
00:00:20.786 --> 00:00:24.120
And particular in this episode,
we're gonna be looking at a global

9
00:00:24.120 --> 00:00:27.580
user interface and ways we can make
changes to that user interface.

10
00:00:27.580 --> 00:00:31.290
And here to show us the way,
is Miss Felicia Duarte.

11
00:00:31.290 --> 00:00:32.360
Welcome back, Felicia.

12
00:00:32.360 --> 00:00:33.790
>> Yes, hello again.

13
00:00:33.790 --> 00:00:37.495
So this topic covers small percentage,

14
00:00:37.495 --> 00:00:41.490
1% of the overall test but
it's a good place to know where to go,

15
00:00:41.490 --> 00:00:46.860
where to navigate, what changes you
can make to the UI of Salesforce

16
00:00:46.860 --> 00:00:51.021
without having to go into any code or
visual force pages.

17
00:00:51.021 --> 00:00:53.770
So I'm gonna start with the basics here.

18
00:00:53.770 --> 00:00:57.610
This way, you might learn something new,
and it might be covered in the test.

19
00:00:57.610 --> 00:00:58.538
You don't know.

20
00:00:58.538 --> 00:01:02.410
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's start with the homepage here.

21
00:01:02.410 --> 00:01:05.470
So I'm gonna start with
these tabs across here,

22
00:01:05.470 --> 00:01:09.310
and we're gonna go through creating
a new app with Salesforce.

23
00:01:09.310 --> 00:01:13.745
So if you hit the + feature here,
this will show you all the available

24
00:01:13.745 --> 00:01:17.734
objects to add to the tabs across
the top of the homepage here.

25
00:01:17.734 --> 00:01:23.149
So I can select Customize My Tabs,
and I can change the order

26
00:01:23.149 --> 00:01:29.700
in which this app that we're in
right now being Sales is displayed.

27
00:01:29.700 --> 00:01:35.570
So moving from up, down will show
things in a left to right view.

28
00:01:35.570 --> 00:01:40.280
So if I were to move, and I normally
have mine situated, I like the Leads,

29
00:01:40.280 --> 00:01:42.920
Accounts, Contacts, Opportunities here.

30
00:01:42.920 --> 00:01:45.710
But sometimes you'll find
it kind of mixed around.

31
00:01:45.710 --> 00:01:50.800
But let's say I don't want
to enable Solutions, so

32
00:01:50.800 --> 00:01:52.350
I'm just gonna move this here.

33
00:01:52.350 --> 00:01:56.390
And right now, without saving, you can see
that Solutions was available up here at

34
00:01:56.390 --> 00:02:01.460
the very top of the Salesforce Sales
app that we're in.

35
00:02:01.460 --> 00:02:04.631
I can hit Save, and that will be removed.

36
00:02:04.631 --> 00:02:07.687
It does not limit the user from seeing it.

37
00:02:07.687 --> 00:02:10.999
There are other ways that
they can navigate to it, so

38
00:02:10.999 --> 00:02:14.255
it's not your place to kind of hide or
restrict it.

39
00:02:14.255 --> 00:02:16.245
It's just visually,

40
00:02:16.245 --> 00:02:21.590
at this point they don't see it,
within this setting here, within this app.

41
00:02:21.590 --> 00:02:23.750
So, let's say you have an org and

42
00:02:23.750 --> 00:02:27.310
you have your sales users set up and
you have your marketing users set up.

43
00:02:27.310 --> 00:02:31.460
You want your marketing users to see
something different than your sales

44
00:02:31.460 --> 00:02:33.110
users or your support users.

45
00:02:33.110 --> 00:02:37.630
So you may want your sales users
to really use the core of the CRM,

46
00:02:37.630 --> 00:02:42.260
which is your leads, your accounts,
contacts, and opportunities.

47
00:02:42.260 --> 00:02:43.200
But if you see here,

48
00:02:43.200 --> 00:02:46.800
these are the default settings that
Salesforce gives you out the box.

49
00:02:47.800 --> 00:02:51.340
So, let's say I wanna move over,
and sometimes you'll see,

50
00:02:51.340 --> 00:02:54.250
right now in developer org,
I'm just gonna see these here.

51
00:02:54.250 --> 00:02:58.450
But, let's say for marketing you
can see the tabs across change.

52
00:02:58.450 --> 00:03:02.260
And I now need access to Campaigns,
not necessarily important for

53
00:03:02.260 --> 00:03:06.190
a sales user to have access to see, but
it kind of just changes the way things

54
00:03:06.190 --> 00:03:09.880
are laid out visually, because as you saw,
too much can be too much sometimes.

55
00:03:09.880 --> 00:03:13.570
And you kinda wanna limit and kinda
show them a quick way, especially for

56
00:03:13.570 --> 00:03:15.600
adoption, where to go.

57
00:03:15.600 --> 00:03:19.960
These are the objects that are relevant
to how you're working in Salesforce.

58
00:03:19.960 --> 00:03:24.690
If you had your support, maybe you just
need to see Accounts, Contacts and Cases.

59
00:03:24.690 --> 00:03:27.010
If you know if they're not managing or

60
00:03:27.010 --> 00:03:31.160
looking at Reports,
then let’s remove the option there too.

61
00:03:31.160 --> 00:03:34.050
>> Really allows you to fine tune
that user interface to what their

62
00:03:34.050 --> 00:03:35.790
role is within your organization.

63
00:03:35.790 --> 00:03:37.400
>> Exactly, right.

64
00:03:37.400 --> 00:03:40.340
So, let's go through
the steps of creating an app.

65
00:03:40.340 --> 00:03:42.320
I mean how customized you can make that.

66
00:03:42.320 --> 00:03:46.010
Right now, what's sort of classic version
and what I like to do anytime I get into

67
00:03:46.010 --> 00:03:50.530
an org, I can see right here on my top
left, this is the release that we're in.

68
00:03:50.530 --> 00:03:52.215
So we're in the Winter 2017 release.

69
00:03:52.215 --> 00:03:55.900
And they do three releases a year,
as I mentioned.

70
00:03:55.900 --> 00:04:00.630
And this will change as it's updated
within Salesforce for every new release.

71

episodes.description: In this episode, Felicia and Mike discuss the Salesforce sharing model. They explain how to secure the organization and then how to open up visibility using role hierarchy, sharing rules and manual sharing.
episodes.title: Security Access
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:01.460
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.460 --> 00:00:02.703
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.703 --> 00:00:06.756
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.756 --> 00:00:08.681
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.681 --> 00:00:10.651
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:10.651 --> 00:00:15.148
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:15.148 --> 00:00:16.897
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

8
00:00:16.897 --> 00:00:20.620
And today, we're doing our sales for
certified administrator.

9
00:00:20.620 --> 00:00:25.250
And in particular in this episode, we're
gonna be taking a look at security access.

10
00:00:25.250 --> 00:00:28.663
And here to help us and
lend her knowledge is Ms. Felicia Duarte.

11
00:00:28.663 --> 00:00:29.948
Good morning, Felicia.

12
00:00:29.948 --> 00:00:31.264
>> Good morning, hello everyone.

13
00:00:31.264 --> 00:00:32.850
Thanks for having me.

14
00:00:32.850 --> 00:00:34.901
So I'm gonna start today
with security access.

15
00:00:34.901 --> 00:00:42.484
Now this covers a second largest piece in
wingout in the exam with about 15% weight.

16
00:00:42.484 --> 00:00:45.619
So this is something you really
wanna study on, brush up on.

17
00:00:45.619 --> 00:00:48.740
I know it can be confusing for some.

18
00:00:48.740 --> 00:00:53.711
So I'm gonna start of with the diagram
to kinda help you understand

19
00:00:53.711 --> 00:00:58.862
the hierarchy of Salesforce as far
as restricting security access,

20
00:00:58.862 --> 00:01:03.333
opening up access,
what that looks like, where to start.

21
00:01:03.333 --> 00:01:05.594
So I'll kinda lead into that and

22
00:01:05.594 --> 00:01:12.210
open up with our drawing that I kinda have
here that Salesforces uses as an example.

23
00:01:12.210 --> 00:01:13.490
And what we have here is
the inverted triangle.

24
00:01:13.490 --> 00:01:17.540
It's maybe to help you understand
better as far as how to open up access

25
00:01:17.540 --> 00:01:18.784
within Salesforce.

26
00:01:18.784 --> 00:01:23.704
So at the very baseline here,
you have what we call the OWDs,

27
00:01:23.704 --> 00:01:26.409
Organization-Wide Defaults.

28
00:01:26.409 --> 00:01:31.320
But before that what really
holds the record ownership would

29
00:01:31.320 --> 00:01:33.059
be the record owner.

30
00:01:33.059 --> 00:01:38.131
So that would really sit right here at
the very bottom as far as ownership goes.

31
00:01:38.131 --> 00:01:42.206
But then working your way
up opens up visibility.

32
00:01:42.206 --> 00:01:47.095
So the Organization-Wide Defaults,
that really restricts access,

33
00:01:47.095 --> 00:01:50.766
that kinda defines within
yourself Salesforce org.

34
00:01:50.766 --> 00:01:56.492
Are you in a private model,
are you locked down, are you in a public

35
00:01:56.492 --> 00:02:03.370
model would be kind of the default
that Salesforce gives out of the box.

36
00:02:03.370 --> 00:02:06.335
But when you wanna start
restricting access and

37
00:02:06.335 --> 00:02:11.384
you wanna move away from a public model,
you're gonna start with the OWDs here.

38
00:02:11.384 --> 00:02:15.027
>> And so this kinda really starts off
secure and then we have to open it up for

39
00:02:15.027 --> 00:02:18.812
people to access, rather than start
off wide open and have to restrict it?

40
00:02:18.812 --> 00:02:20.361
>> Well actually the opposite.

41
00:02:20.361 --> 00:02:23.342
So by default it starts out public.
