So it's gonna go based off
the field that you chose.

331
00:19:40.022 --> 00:19:41.617
So if you chose a currency fields, so

332
00:19:41.617 --> 00:19:44.090
it has to be in that decimal
point that we defined it in.

333
00:19:44.090 --> 00:19:49.640
You can have other validations set up
within any field or object in Salesforce.

334
00:19:49.640 --> 00:19:51.960
But right now, we can see that
the fields that we've created,

335
00:19:51.960 --> 00:19:54.840
there's no sections at this
point with this new object.

336
00:19:54.840 --> 00:19:57.610
The fields would just
continue to fall under here.

337
00:19:57.610 --> 00:20:01.050
But, you start building out
the new object that you created,

338
00:20:01.050 --> 00:20:05.050
and you do that by visually
changing the layout or

339
00:20:05.050 --> 00:20:08.990
you can continue building on
the field that you're in.

340
00:20:08.990 --> 00:20:11.360
Now to without a test record,

341
00:20:11.360 --> 00:20:15.670
the only other way to kind of navigate
back would be to set up, to search for

342
00:20:15.670 --> 00:20:19.520
objects and then to go into that
custom object that you built out.

343
00:20:19.520 --> 00:20:25.080
But I always like to have a test record
to easily navigate back into the object,

344
00:20:25.080 --> 00:20:29.010
and then continue building
out some of those fields.

345
00:20:29.010 --> 00:20:31.790
So we're back here,
I'm gonna select a New.

346
00:20:33.080 --> 00:20:34.410
And everything else, for

347
00:20:34.410 --> 00:20:40.210
the most part, unless one catches my mind,
you have date, date and time.

348
00:20:40.210 --> 00:20:46.710
If you're looking to generate a report,
let's say, I'm sorry, generate a formula

349
00:20:46.710 --> 00:20:50.945
using two dates, you gotta make sure that
you make the date/time just a date field.

350
00:20:50.945 --> 00:20:56.330
E-mail field has to be, has validation
to have a standard e-mail field,

351
00:20:56.330 --> 00:20:58.392
so it has to have the @ on it.

352
00:20:58.392 --> 00:21:03.570
Geolocation, so a number,
a number will always have a comma in it.

353
00:21:03.570 --> 00:21:08.530
If you're looking to have a number that
you do not want to create that for,

354
00:21:08.530 --> 00:21:12.970
create that field as a text field,
and then Picklist and Multi-Select.

355
00:21:12.970 --> 00:21:16.130
So you can have Multi-Select Picklist,
you can have Picklist, but

356
00:21:16.130 --> 00:21:19.101
you can also have depended Picklist.

357
00:21:19.101 --> 00:21:24.621
So if you want one value in that Picklist
to then show you another field that

358
00:21:24.621 --> 00:21:29.712
needs to be generated from it,
you create that relationship here.

359
00:21:29.712 --> 00:21:33.059
So in this one we would first
have that Picklist created and

360
00:21:33.059 --> 00:21:36.560
then you create the second Picklist and
do that dependency.

361
00:21:38.470 --> 00:21:42.020
And then as I'm going through
this you have about five

362
00:21:42.020 --> 00:21:43.970
different text options to have.

363
00:21:43.970 --> 00:21:48.850
So you can have a text,
a small text box combination that's

364
00:21:48.850 --> 00:21:53.000
alpha numeric of letters and numbers and
then a text area which is smaller.

365
00:21:53.000 --> 00:21:57.760
255 characters, but for those that need
to collect or hold more information,

366
00:21:57.760 --> 00:21:59.460
you wanna go with the long text area.

367
00:21:59.460 --> 00:22:03.155
And if you needed to collect
maybe an image or a picture,

368
00:22:03.155 --> 00:22:06.073
you can have it sit under
as a rich text area.

369
00:22:06.073 --> 00:22:08.540
So keep that in mind when
you're doing data imports.

370
00:22:08.540 --> 00:22:11.550
And know the numbers as far
as your limitation goes for

371
00:22:11.550 --> 00:22:14.660
each one of these that
can be asked on the exam.

372
00:22:14.660 --> 00:22:19.410
And then also know that when
you enter in you store images

373
00:22:19.410 --> 00:22:23.860
within those rich text fields that
does weigh into your data space too.

374
00:22:23.860 --> 00:22:29.060
And then you also have text encrypted,
which is often used for, and

375
00:22:29.060 --> 00:22:36.360
I've seen this in the test too, let's
say Social Security and let's put 10.

376
00:22:36.360 --> 00:22:39.420
I believe it's more digits than that but
you do want to include the dash in there.

377
00:22:39.420 --> 00:22:44.801
Then you have, for this specific encrypted
field, you've got the length to add, you

378
00:22:44.801 --> 00:22:49.610
have to enter the API name, description
and text, whether it's required.

379
00:22:49.610 --> 00:22:52.921
And then because we decided to
go with an encrypted field,

380
00:22:52.921 --> 00:22:56.010
should it follow a Social Security number?

381
00:22:56.010 --> 00:23:00.334
If we choose that, this dependent
Picklist here will ask which one.

382
00:23:00.334 --> 00:23:04.413
And then credit card information
is often used for this, so

383
00:23:04.413 --> 00:23:08.480
do you wanna mask all characters,
the last four?

384
00:23:08.480 --> 00:23:09.630
Credit card number, so

385
00:23:09.630 --> 00:23:13.590
these are your options here when you're
creating an encrypted field in Salesforce.

386
00:23:16.730 --> 00:23:20.436
So I'm gonna select
Social Security Number, and Next, and

387
00:23:20.436 --> 00:23:24.370
I may have not selected my Mask Character,
I'm gonna go with X.

388
00:23:24.370 --> 00:23:27.836
And this will show you an example
of what it would look like.

389
00:23:27.836 --> 00:23:35.820
And you're starting to see
the prompts after you save a field.

390
00:23:37.080 --> 00:23:40.850
And if I select Save & New this time,
then we're taken right back to this page

391
00:23:40.850 --> 00:23:43.080
here to continue to build and
add to fields.

392
00:23:43.080 --> 00:23:48.710
And then, lastly, you have the URL for new
websites that you wanna add to the record.

393
00:23:53.205 --> 00:23:56.188
So we come back into this text record,

394
00:23:56.188 --> 00:24:00.870
you can see here some of
the three fields that we added.

395
00:24:00.870 --> 00:24:03.490
You can kinda start seeing
the build out here,

396
00:24:03.490 --> 00:24:06.990
and the validation at each
of those fields can have.

397
00:24:08.280 --> 00:24:10.810
>> And now Felicia earlier you
had mention junction objects,

398
00:24:10.810 --> 00:24:12.186
can you tell me a little
bit more about this?

399
00:24:12.186 --> 00:24:14.180
>> Yes, so for a junction object,

400
00:24:14.180 --> 00:24:18.560
you would be creating another object to
associate two other objects to each other.

401
00:24:18.560 --> 00:24:22.560
So it's kinda gonna be your junction and
connection between two different objects.

402
00:24:22.560 --> 00:24:25.503
And sometimes that's just
the creation of one or

403
00:24:25.503 --> 00:24:29.290
two fields in order to connect
those two objects together.

404
00:24:29.290 --> 00:24:32.070
>> You got two objects that maybe
aren't directly related, but

405
00:24:32.070 --> 00:24:34.070
we can tie them together
with a third object.

406
00:24:34.070 --> 00:24:35.320
>> Exactly, right.

407
00:24:35.320 --> 00:24:36.780
>> Very good, very good.

408
00:24:36.780 --> 00:24:38.740
All right Felicia,
tell you about a great look there.

409
00:24:38.740 --> 00:24:42.355
Really showed us what we can do with
the standard objects that come with

410
00:24:42.355 --> 00:24:47.330
Salesforce, the out of box, and we also
looked at making those custom objects and

411
00:24:47.330 --> 00:24:51.850
just unbelievably customizable
what we can do with those objects.

412
00:24:51.850 --> 00:24:52.600
So, we thank you for

413
00:24:52.600 --> 00:24:55.800
that look, we hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching this one.

414
00:24:55.800 --> 00:24:58.930
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

415
00:24:58.930 --> 00:25:00.294
>> I'm Felicia Duarte.

416
00:25:00.294 --> 00:25:01.352
>> And we'll see you next time.

417
00:25:01.352 --> 00:25:08.425
[MUSIC]

418
00:25:08.425 --> 00:25:10.720
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Felicia and Mike look at leveraging campaigns in Salesforce. They demonstrate creating campaigns and campaign reports. They also look at target lists and tracking responses.
episodes.title: Campaigns
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.200
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.200 --> 00:00:02.856
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.856 --> 00:00:06.566
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.566 --> 00:00:08.319
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.319 --> 00:00:12.174
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.174 --> 00:00:15.958
>> Hello welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.958 --> 00:00:17.362
I'm your host Mike Roderick and

8
00:00:17.362 --> 00:00:20.120
today we're doing our Salesforce
certified administrator.

9
00:00:20.120 --> 00:00:22.870
And in this episode we're
gonna be looking at.

10
00:00:22.870 --> 00:00:27.040
How we can create and
use campaigns within Salesforce.

11
00:00:27.040 --> 00:00:29.810
And here to show us the way
is Miss Felicia Duarte.

12
00:00:29.810 --> 00:00:31.070
Welcome back Felicia.

13
00:00:31.070 --> 00:00:32.660
>> Great, thanks for having me.

14
00:00:32.660 --> 00:00:35.985
So on today's episode I'm
gonna go through campaigns.

15
00:00:35.985 --> 00:00:42.115
Campaign in the exam goes in hand in hand,
and it's part of the sales weight.

16
00:00:42.115 --> 00:00:47.225
So it's gonna part of that 9% that we went
through in one of our previous episodes.

17
00:00:47.225 --> 00:00:51.662
So today's goal in this episode is to
go through the campaigns, the setup and

18
00:00:51.662 --> 00:00:56.170
creation of a campaign, generating
target list, adding campaign members,

19
00:00:56.170 --> 00:01:00.700
editing campaign members, making changes
to some of those standard fields.

20
00:01:00.700 --> 00:01:02.540
Campaigns is a standard object.

21
00:01:02.540 --> 00:01:05.090
And, then, what's the ROI reporting on it?

22
00:01:05.090 --> 00:01:09.210
What's the influence that my campaign
has on my overall opportunities.

23
00:01:09.210 --> 00:01:12.050
So to start let's go through with the who.

24
00:01:12.050 --> 00:01:14.590
So who has access to campaigns?

25
00:01:14.590 --> 00:01:16.330
Who can set up campaigns?

26
00:01:16.330 --> 00:01:22.390
Now by default with Salesforce, every
user has a read only access to campaigns.

27
00:01:22.390 --> 00:01:28.480
If you want to give an individual more
access to edit the campaign records or

28
00:01:28.480 --> 00:01:31.180
add members to the campaign records or
import.

29
00:01:31.180 --> 00:01:36.110
You want to make sure that in the user
they have selected a marketing user.

30
00:01:36.110 --> 00:01:39.150
Once that's selected and
saved they will have more access

31
00:01:39.150 --> 00:01:44.560
to make changes within the marketing
app within Salesforce.

32
00:01:44.560 --> 00:01:47.710
So to start let's move and change apps.

33
00:01:47.710 --> 00:01:50.420
And work within the campaign
object in SalesForce.

34
00:01:51.420 --> 00:01:54.830
So we're in the sales app,
let's move over into marketing.

35
00:01:54.830 --> 00:01:57.007
And as we move over
into the marketing app,

36
00:01:57.007 --> 00:01:59.620
we're gonna see that
the tabs across here change.

37
00:02:00.660 --> 00:02:03.680
Well let's navigate over into
our campaign's object, here.

38
00:02:05.280 --> 00:02:09.170
So, before setup you want to create,
or before adding any members,

39
00:02:09.170 --> 00:02:13.310
you wanna figure out what's your strategy,
what is your marketing strategy.

40
00:02:13.310 --> 00:02:17.440
Now you can use campaigns to
generate to new leads, or

41
00:02:17.440 --> 00:02:20.680
you can use this to build your brand.

42
00:02:20.680 --> 00:02:25.880
Reach out, have engagement with some of
your existing contacts in Salesforce.

43
00:02:25.880 --> 00:02:30.250
So to start let's look at
one of the out the box

44
00:02:30.250 --> 00:02:33.220
Salesforce campaigns
gives you as an example.

45
00:02:33.220 --> 00:02:37.850
So right now we're looking at a recent
campaign, DM campaigns to top customers.

46
00:02:37.850 --> 00:02:40.340
Just staying here at our
home page you can see,

47
00:02:40.340 --> 00:02:46.200
you can directly navigate to a campaign
ROI report, to a revenue report,

48
00:02:46.200 --> 00:02:49.830
or to a member analysis report
directly from your home page here.

49
00:02:49.830 --> 00:02:52.250
But if we move over into this campaign.

50
00:02:53.440 --> 00:02:56.170
So at this part right here we
have the campaign details.

51
00:02:56.170 --> 00:03:00.440
So some of these fields, or all of these
fields, are standard fields of Salesforce.

52
00:03:00.440 --> 00:03:03.190
What you want to do is you want
to have enter a campaign name.

53
00:03:03.190 --> 00:03:05.880
You want to select if it's active.

54
00:03:05.880 --> 00:03:08.310
And then some of these fields here
that are centered of Selfforce.

55
00:03:08.310 --> 00:03:09.270
You want to make changes so

56
00:03:09.270 --> 00:03:13.030
that it applies to the business
model that you're in.

57
00:03:13.030 --> 00:03:16.880
Does it fit for you that you attend trade
shows or that you want to keep track for

58
00:03:16.880 --> 00:03:20.210
campaigns partners or referral programs.

59
00:03:20.210 --> 00:03:21.880
Make changes, add, edit or

60
00:03:21.880 --> 00:03:27.410
rename some of the values here prior
to setting up your marketing campaigns.

61
00:03:27.410 --> 00:03:28.380
And then what's the status?

62
00:03:28.380 --> 00:03:31.260
Is it something that's been
you're in the planning stages,

63
00:03:31.260 --> 00:03:35.670
is it in progress,
something that you aborted or completed.

64
00:03:35.670 --> 00:03:40.550
So you can have previous
existing campaigns pushed in.

65
00:03:40.550 --> 00:03:43.920
And then if it's an event,
what's the start date and end date?

66
00:03:43.920 --> 00:03:47.450
And then what is the expected
revenue you're looking to generate

67
00:03:47.450 --> 00:03:49.360
from the specific campaign?

68
00:03:49.360 --> 00:03:53.090
It's important to also have
the budgeted cost and the actual cost.

69
00:03:53.090 --> 00:03:56.360
So with Salesforce,
an important report is the ROI report.

70
00:03:56.360 --> 00:03:59.600
So the actual cost is gonna play a role

71
00:03:59.600 --> 00:04:03.170
in generating what that ROI
percentage actually is.

72
00:04:03.170 --> 00:04:05.570
So if you have that number, enter it in.

73
00:04:05.570 --> 00:04:06.650
And then some of the other fields but

74
00:04:06.650 --> 00:04:09.600
it's not required would be
what's the expected response?

75
00:04:09.600 --> 00:04:12.190
The percentage of this marketing campaign.

76
00:04:12.190 --> 00:04:14.200
And then how many people
are you sending it to?

77
00:04:14.200 --> 00:04:18.690
So all of these fields are standard of
Salesforce but you can also use them to

78
00:04:18.690 --> 00:04:25.270
generate our create formulas and build off
more specific or fine tuned reporting.

79
00:04:26.750 --> 00:04:28.490
And can customize that too.

80
00:04:28.490 --> 00:04:30.800
So and then does this belong
to a parent's campaign?

81
00:04:30.800 --> 00:04:33.620
So similar to accounts, parent and

82
00:04:33.620 --> 00:04:36.850
child records, you can also have
the same with your campaigns.

83
00:04:36.850 --> 00:04:40.350
And so if that was related,
you would use a lookup feature here and

84
00:04:40.350 --> 00:04:44.560
lookup to an existing campaign
to set that hierarchy.

85
00:04:44.560 --> 00:04:49.760
So, I'm gonna go back into the homepage
of our campaign detail, and

86
00:04:49.760 --> 00:04:53.210
I'm gonna go through managing
the members of your campaign.

87
00:04:53.210 --> 00:04:57.110
Now, you can manage the members in
three different ways within Salesforce.

88
00:04:57.110 --> 00:05:00.010
So, you can manage your
members individually.

89
00:05:00.010 --> 00:05:04.330
You can go into a lead record or
a contact record, and

90
00:05:04.330 --> 00:05:06.660
just add into an existing campaign.

91
00:05:06.660 --> 00:05:09.130
So as long as a campaign is active,
this is existing,

92
00:05:09.130 --> 00:05:15.240
we can add those members individually and
then into list views or reports.

93
00:05:15.240 --> 00:05:18.170
So let's go into a lead object.

94
00:05:18.170 --> 00:05:22.980
And you can create, you want to
first after you've defined what

95
00:05:22.980 --> 00:05:27.730
your marketing strategy is the next
question is who is my target list.

96
00:05:27.730 --> 00:05:31.380
Who am I trying to target
with this campaign?

97
00:05:31.380 --> 00:05:35.390
And you set that criteria in your
reports or in your list views.

98
00:05:35.390 --> 00:05:37.930
So maybe there's a geographical
that you look at.

99
00:05:37.930 --> 00:05:39.700
Or even an age.

100
00:05:39.700 --> 00:05:44.200
Any field, and that can be a custom field
that you create within the lead and

101
00:05:44.200 --> 00:05:45.360
contact.

102
00:05:45.360 --> 00:05:48.150
You can build off these lists and reports.

103
00:05:48.150 --> 00:05:51.770
Just like you would the same way
in any lists view within the lead.

104
00:05:52.940 --> 00:05:54.510
Our contact object.

105
00:05:54.510 --> 00:05:57.150
So if I were to go back
into my lead homepage here.

106
00:05:58.910 --> 00:06:01.930
And let's use the example of
all open leads and hit go.

107
00:06:03.210 --> 00:06:08.350
You can see the button at the very top
of this list view page, add to campaign.

108
00:06:08.350 --> 00:06:11.360
So I need to select
a list of all my leads.

109
00:06:11.360 --> 00:06:15.090
And if this was already fit with
the criteria I wanted to give it.

110
00:06:15.090 --> 00:06:19.000
So all CEOs in a fortune five
hundred company that make

111
00:06:19.000 --> 00:06:23.490
have the annual revenue of
over $1 billion as an example.

112
00:06:23.490 --> 00:06:26.960
Only that set of users will show here.

113
00:06:26.960 --> 00:06:28.855
And then you can just select all and
it's just.

114
00:06:28.855 --> 00:06:30.635
Easier to add to a campaign.

115
00:06:30.635 --> 00:06:33.285
If I added this review
users to the campaign,

116
00:06:33.285 --> 00:06:37.197
once selected I'm gonna use my look up
field and search for an existing campaign.

117
00:06:37.197 --> 00:06:39.565
So we're gonna use this one here, and

118
00:06:39.565 --> 00:06:43.205
my member status will apply to
all the users that are selected.

119
00:06:44.445 --> 00:06:47.305
So sent for this example, and
and let's select add to campaign.

120
00:06:49.170 --> 00:06:50.830
So these are new members.

121
00:06:50.830 --> 00:06:52.550
These members already existed.

122
00:06:52.550 --> 00:06:56.160
I used this group of members
previously to add them to the campaign.

123
00:06:56.160 --> 00:06:58.740
But if they were new, you would see
the amount of new members added.

124
00:06:58.740 --> 00:07:00.290
So I'm gonna select done.

125
00:07:00.290 --> 00:07:02.620
And now if we go into the campaign itself.

126
00:07:02.620 --> 00:07:07.820
Let's go into the recent items,
navigate there.

127
00:07:07.820 --> 00:07:10.840
If I scroll to the bottom,
we're gonna see a list of those members,

128
00:07:10.840 --> 00:07:14.600
so it was sent with their
contact information and

129
00:07:14.600 --> 00:07:18.400
any of the columns I feel is
relevant to see at a glance.

130
00:07:18.400 --> 00:07:20.520
Now you can add from this related list,

131
00:07:20.520 --> 00:07:26.010
so this is your related list of campaign
members within the campaign object.

132
00:07:26.010 --> 00:07:28.430
You have your option
to manage the members,

133
00:07:28.430 --> 00:07:33.410
make changes to the members via an import
file if you want to add new members, or

134
00:07:33.410 --> 00:07:35.540
if you want to do a mass update.

135
00:07:35.540 --> 00:07:39.220
You can keep track of their responses.

136
00:07:39.220 --> 00:07:42.550
The responses to the campaign
can come in in different ways.

137
00:07:42.550 --> 00:07:47.640
So maybe some of the responses
are sent through email.

138
00:07:47.640 --> 00:07:51.870
You can have that either manually managed,
or you can have the imports come in and

139
00:07:51.870 --> 00:07:55.030
update itself within Salesforce.

140
00:07:55.030 --> 00:07:56.490
So you have these options to update,

141
00:07:56.490 --> 00:08:00.560
edit, and
add new members to the campaign itself.

142
00:08:00.560 --> 00:08:04.120
Now a great feature too that
Salesforce has is campaign influence.

143
00:08:04.120 --> 00:08:08.760
So if we navigate over to the setup and
go into quick find campaign,

144
00:08:10.590 --> 00:08:13.070
we see the subsection below
you have campaign influence.

145
00:08:13.070 --> 00:08:18.090
Now if you just change your settings,
the first step would be to enable it.

146
00:08:18.090 --> 00:08:20.920
I've gone in here already and
already enabled our campaign influence.

147
00:08:20.920 --> 00:08:25.810
And then the next steps would
be to select that association.

148
00:08:25.810 --> 00:08:30.950
So what criteria do you wanna give it,
to societe that it has been related and

149
00:08:30.950 --> 00:08:32.570
it's generated these opportunities?

150
00:08:32.570 --> 00:08:34.640
So within a given time period,

151
00:08:34.640 --> 00:08:38.630
that my campaign has been active
you set that time period.

152
00:08:38.630 --> 00:08:40.330
We're using the example of 30 days.

153
00:08:41.350 --> 00:08:46.350
Any opportunities that were created or
generated from the criteria that we give

154
00:08:46.350 --> 00:08:51.950
it will then display in a related list,
called Campaign Influence.

155
00:08:51.950 --> 00:08:56.460
And that will show you the influence
that that campaign has, for

156
00:08:56.460 --> 00:09:00.590
those given opportunities, and
you can generate a report from it, and

157
00:09:00.590 --> 00:09:06.370
you can see how effective
is this campaign.

158
00:09:06.370 --> 00:09:09.230
So, it's a common question
I've see on test.

159
00:09:09.230 --> 00:09:10.660
What's the time frame?

160
00:09:10.660 --> 00:09:12.000
Can I leave this blank?

161
00:09:12.000 --> 00:09:16.870
You certainly can't leave it blank, but
if you do enter a number 9,999 is the max

162
00:09:16.870 --> 00:09:22.670
amount of days that you can enter for
a given influence.

163
00:09:23.900 --> 00:09:25.132
So if I were to hit Save,

164
00:09:25.132 --> 00:09:29.027
then you would see this pop up as
a related list within your opportunities.

165
00:09:31.081 --> 00:09:33.401
So let's navigate back to the campaign.

166
00:09:35.314 --> 00:09:36.470
Object.

167
00:09:36.470 --> 00:09:39.795
And so, this right now tells us
that we have an active campaign,

168
00:09:39.795 --> 00:09:43.570
this is the total number of leads,
if there were any converted leads.

169
00:09:43.570 --> 00:09:45.760
The influence in all your
responses will show here.

170
00:09:45.760 --> 00:09:50.280
What's my total contacts,
if you pulled them from lead and contacts.

171
00:09:50.280 --> 00:09:53.130
And then a total number of opportunities
that have been generated during this

172
00:09:53.130 --> 00:09:54.620
given time period.

173
00:09:54.620 --> 00:09:58.510
Another great tool that I had mentioned
previously would be the reports

174
00:09:58.510 --> 00:09:59.960
that come from this.

175
00:09:59.960 --> 00:10:04.570
So if we go down, you can utilize
the standard reports, which are great,

176
00:10:04.570 --> 00:10:07.260
and you can go back into
your homepages there.

177
00:10:07.260 --> 00:10:11.271
Or you can also build off reports and
build off from those influences.

178
00:10:11.271 --> 00:10:16.580
What are my leads or
contacts associated with given campaigns.

179
00:10:16.580 --> 00:10:21.630
You can generate it that way or
you can just go directly into your

180
00:10:21.630 --> 00:10:25.110
homepage here and
use a campaign ROI analysis report.

181
00:10:26.550 --> 00:10:30.680
Now from here you can see, automatically
it's gonna look at your campaign names,

182
00:10:30.680 --> 00:10:32.410
it's gonna pull up a list
of all of them and

183
00:10:32.410 --> 00:10:35.160
it's gonna show you the different
types that you have running.

184
00:10:35.160 --> 00:10:37.470
And it's gonna show you
the actual cost and

185
00:10:37.470 --> 00:10:41.750
that's going off the field that we
previously saw within the campaign record.

186
00:10:41.750 --> 00:10:43.280
And then it's gonna pull off.

187
00:10:43.280 --> 00:10:49.700
And this is a report formula
called a ROI percentage formula.

188
00:10:49.700 --> 00:10:52.297
And what that one is gonna give you,

189
00:10:52.297 --> 00:10:57.060
it's gonna give you the total value
all of your opportunities for

190
00:10:57.060 --> 00:11:02.963
that given campaign and it's gonna go
ahead and take that minus the actual cost.

191
00:11:02.963 --> 00:11:06.987
So that's why the actual cost is important
to have and then it's gonna divide that

192
00:11:06.987 --> 00:11:10.450
again by the actual cost to
give you the percentage number.

193
00:11:10.450 --> 00:11:13.080
So that's something that you do
want to keep in mind when you're

194
00:11:13.080 --> 00:11:14.150
generating this report.

195
00:11:14.150 --> 00:11:18.207
And you can use some of those other
fields to generate your own custom built

196
00:11:18.207 --> 00:11:18.870
formulas.

197
00:11:18.870 --> 00:11:19.490
>> Fantastic.

198
00:11:19.490 --> 00:11:24.190
I mean, incredibly robust system for
working with campaigns but then tying

199
00:11:24.190 --> 00:11:28.170
everything together and really showing me,
iss this campaign producing anything?

200
00:11:28.170 --> 00:11:31.880
Are we actually making any new contacts,
or converting any leads,

201
00:11:31.880 --> 00:11:33.220
or making any money?

202
00:11:33.220 --> 00:11:35.870
Is it worth what we're
spending on this campaign?

203
00:11:35.870 --> 00:11:36.640
So, fantastic.

204
00:11:36.640 --> 00:11:39.530
We appreciate that in-depth
look at what we can

205
00:11:39.530 --> 00:11:41.410
do with campaigns within Salesforce.

206
00:11:41.410 --> 00:11:43.560
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

207
00:11:43.560 --> 00:11:46.710
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been you're host, Mike Roderick.

208
00:11:46.710 --> 00:11:47.710
>> I'm Felicia Dougherty.

209
00:11:47.710 --> 00:11:50.374
>> And we'll see you next time.

210
00:11:50.374 --> 00:11:56.314
[MUSIC]

211
00:11:56.314 --> 00:11:59.077
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Felicia and Mike look at service and support in Salesforce. They explain case management, and escalation and assignment rules. They also look at case reports.
episodes.title: Service and Support
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.210
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:08.346
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.346 --> 00:00:12.322
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.322 --> 00:00:15.590
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:15.590 --> 00:00:17.480
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:17.480 --> 00:00:20.740
And today we're doing our
Salesforce Certified Administrator.

7
00:00:20.740 --> 00:00:24.250
And in this episode we're gonna be
looking at service and support, and

8
00:00:24.250 --> 00:00:27.170
how we can work with
cases within Salesforce.

9
00:00:27.170 --> 00:00:29.840
And here, to lend us her
support is Miss Felicia Duarte.

10
00:00:29.840 --> 00:00:30.930
Welcome back, Felicia.

11
00:00:30.930 --> 00:00:32.170
>> Great, thank you.

12
00:00:32.170 --> 00:00:35.750
So on this episode today,
I'm gonna cover cases and solution.

13
00:00:35.750 --> 00:00:38.540
This accounts for 6% of the exam in

14
00:00:38.540 --> 00:00:43.384
the support section within
Salesforce certification exam.

15
00:00:43.384 --> 00:00:45.540
So, let's go through and start with cases.

16
00:00:45.540 --> 00:00:48.080
Case management and sales force,
so let's define that.

17
00:00:48.080 --> 00:00:50.664
What is case management and sales force?

18
00:00:50.664 --> 00:00:54.690
It's tracking any of those
customer complaints, issues.

19
00:00:54.690 --> 00:00:57.070
Think of it as a ticketing system.

20
00:00:57.070 --> 00:01:00.455
Just to manage and
automate those processes and

21
00:01:00.455 --> 00:01:03.900
responses quicker within Salesforce.

22
00:01:03.900 --> 00:01:07.140
So, let's navigate over and
change the tab that we're in.

23
00:01:07.140 --> 00:01:10.440
Right now, where in the marketing tab for
one of our previous episodes.

24
00:01:10.440 --> 00:01:15.970
But, let's move over into the call
center and pull in the case object.

25
00:01:15.970 --> 00:01:18.380
Now, not everyone's gonna have access.

26
00:01:18.380 --> 00:01:22.430
Maybe you just have a support team,
managing some of those tickets or

27
00:01:22.430 --> 00:01:25.730
problems or
areas that interact with your customers.

28
00:01:25.730 --> 00:01:30.850
So, maybe only a specific group of users
need to have access to this app here, and

29
00:01:30.850 --> 00:01:31.480
the objects.

30
00:01:31.480 --> 00:01:33.770
So, now that I switched
over to our call center,

31
00:01:33.770 --> 00:01:37.880
we can see two new objects brought
over to the top of these tabs here.

32
00:01:37.880 --> 00:01:40.060
We have cases, And we have solutions,

33
00:01:40.060 --> 00:01:44.770
so let's jump into the case object and
case homepage.

34
00:01:44.770 --> 00:01:47.730
You're gonna see a list of
some of your recent cases, and

35
00:01:47.730 --> 00:01:52.040
then you have a few reports and tools to
work off directly from your homepage here.

36
00:01:52.040 --> 00:01:56.690
So, you can jump into the total
cases created, who it's created by,

37
00:01:56.690 --> 00:02:02.020
who the agent or the Salesforce user,
that's gonna be used interchangeably.

38
00:02:02.020 --> 00:02:04.080
And then, what's the history report?

39
00:02:04.080 --> 00:02:07.400
What's the time and some standard
reports or what's the timing and

40
00:02:07.400 --> 00:02:11.760
completion to making this case
resolved from the start date?

41
00:02:11.760 --> 00:02:15.220
And then, some tools you can even
mass email some of your cases or

42
00:02:15.220 --> 00:02:17.230
mass delete cases.

43
00:02:17.230 --> 00:02:21.480
I'll jump into the mass email cases just
to show you, you're looking at list of all

44
00:02:21.480 --> 00:02:27.400
my cases right now and if I select to go,
you'll see what cases are available and

45
00:02:27.400 --> 00:02:30.990
this is by default in the developer
org it's some of the sample cases.

46
00:02:30.990 --> 00:02:34.500
But you can select all or
select one or two, and

47
00:02:34.500 --> 00:02:39.470
you can have some templates already
pre-bit built out related to some of this

48
00:02:39.470 --> 00:02:44.420
case management or support management
to enhance your customers experience.

49
00:02:44.420 --> 00:02:49.540
And proof from any of this account didn't
take the next step to the sending out

50
00:02:49.540 --> 00:02:54.680
that email, out that group of users or
contacts of yours.

51
00:02:54.680 --> 00:02:57.540
So, going back to your case,
let's go over here.

52
00:02:57.540 --> 00:02:59.560
And go into a case record.

53
00:02:59.560 --> 00:03:03.980
Now, you can see the layout of this
change for your support users.

54
00:03:03.980 --> 00:03:07.920
To your left, you have general
information about the contact itself.

55
00:03:07.920 --> 00:03:11.830
So, we can see the customer name
if she pertained to a company, and

56
00:03:11.830 --> 00:03:13.120
the phone number.

57
00:03:13.120 --> 00:03:15.640
The related list show to your left here.

58
00:03:15.640 --> 00:03:18.500
So, we'll touch base in a bit solutions,
but

59
00:03:18.500 --> 00:03:22.370
if there were case teams related
to this case, or emails and

60
00:03:22.370 --> 00:03:26.260
related cases, all of that will
populate to your left now.

61
00:03:26.260 --> 00:03:29.570
And the details show in
this details column here.

62
00:03:30.620 --> 00:03:34.456
By default, I had worked on this record
already and navigated to details, but

63
00:03:34.456 --> 00:03:36.563
by default you're taken to the feed here.

64
00:03:36.563 --> 00:03:38.195
And this is related to your chatter feed.

65
00:03:38.195 --> 00:03:41.280
So, if there was anything
related you would see it here.

66
00:03:41.280 --> 00:03:45.710
But, to pull in the details you wanna make
sure you grab into the details section.

67
00:03:45.710 --> 00:03:49.855
And you can see some of the standard
fields that sales force gives you.

68
00:03:49.855 --> 00:03:53.935
So, do not create any custom fields,
this is what you have to work off.

69
00:03:53.935 --> 00:03:57.665
There are a few ways that
these cases can be generated.

70
00:03:57.665 --> 00:04:00.867
So, the cases can be
generated via an email.

71
00:04:00.867 --> 00:04:04.185
So, Salesforce has what's
called the email to case and

72
00:04:04.185 --> 00:04:09.720
you can set up your support email,
that you have for a company.

73
00:04:09.720 --> 00:04:14.670
And any email sent to that email address
or support email address that you

74
00:04:14.670 --> 00:04:20.040
define in the setup, will then generate
cases automatically into Salesforce.

75
00:04:20.040 --> 00:04:24.050
So, if we look back here at our detail
page, you can see the subject, and

76
00:04:24.050 --> 00:04:25.370
that's gonna pull it from the email.

77
00:04:25.370 --> 00:04:28.514
And in the body of that will
live within description.

78
00:04:28.514 --> 00:04:32.770
So, sometimes you may have cases
with very little information.

79
00:04:32.770 --> 00:04:36.350
Salesforce is gonna look
to the email address first,

80
00:04:36.350 --> 00:04:39.170
to associate it to maybe
any given contact.

81
00:04:39.170 --> 00:04:43.170
So, if the record exist it's
gonna create a case for

82
00:04:43.170 --> 00:04:46.100
the existing contact in Salesforce.

83
00:04:46.100 --> 00:04:47.870
And if it does not find a matching email,

84
00:04:47.870 --> 00:04:51.300
you're gonna create a new contact and
a new case.

85
00:04:51.300 --> 00:04:55.000
Now, you're gonna have very
little information at this point.

86
00:04:55.000 --> 00:04:58.002
So, you can enter new fields if
its related to a certain service

87
00:04:58.002 --> 00:04:59.427
that you provide or product.

88
00:04:59.427 --> 00:05:04.973
When you're trying to troubleshoot
what common areas of issues you have,

89
00:05:04.973 --> 00:05:06.920
or how will you handle it?

90
00:05:06.920 --> 00:05:09.526
So, right now,
we're just working off of the case reason.

91
00:05:09.526 --> 00:05:14.740
So, cases aren't always bad things,
you can also have positive feedback.

92
00:05:14.740 --> 00:05:18.830
Maybe you wanna keep track in future
reports what some of my feedback and

93
00:05:18.830 --> 00:05:20.194
negative feedback, or

94
00:05:20.194 --> 00:05:24.160
what are some common issues that
your org is experiencing as a whole.

95
00:05:24.160 --> 00:05:26.779
So, this way you can kinda breakdown and

96
00:05:26.779 --> 00:05:30.890
figure out ways how to improve
your customer success.

97
00:05:30.890 --> 00:05:35.063
So, if I double click into here some of
these may apply to your business model and

98
00:05:35.063 --> 00:05:35.820
some may not.

99
00:05:35.820 --> 00:05:39.612
So, I would go in previews and
make those changes as a system admin, and

100
00:05:39.612 --> 00:05:43.780
make sure that everything is fine
tuned to fit your business needs.

101
00:05:43.780 --> 00:05:48.210
So, do you provide a service that needs
installation is there a breakdown

102
00:05:48.210 --> 00:05:49.434
equipment design.

103
00:05:49.434 --> 00:05:56.200
Anything you pretty granular here, you can
start associating with the product itself.

104
00:05:56.200 --> 00:06:00.850
And this is all directly related
to just the case details.

105
00:06:00.850 --> 00:06:05.690
Other series of questions
that you ask your caller or

106
00:06:05.690 --> 00:06:10.310
contact that you wanna keep and store
here, then create some custom fields.

107
00:06:10.310 --> 00:06:13.130
But right now,
pretty you just have priority.

108
00:06:13.130 --> 00:06:16.090
So, the priority's gonna be low,
medium, or high.

109
00:06:16.090 --> 00:06:19.470
And then,
a standard field is what is the status?

110
00:06:19.470 --> 00:06:21.214
So, is this case a new case?

111
00:06:21.214 --> 00:06:22.528
Are you still working on it?

112
00:06:22.528 --> 00:06:25.930
Does it need to be
escalated at this point?

113
00:06:25.930 --> 00:06:28.990
Which we'll get into as far
as case escalation rules.

114
00:06:28.990 --> 00:06:32.830
And then,
aside from the case reason on the type.

115
00:06:32.830 --> 00:06:36.205
So, if your business is broken
up into different areas, or

116
00:06:36.205 --> 00:06:41.064
maybe you just have one service, but you
could have different scenarios that you're

117
00:06:41.064 --> 00:06:44.993
trying to keep track of,
utilize the type field within Salesforce.

118
00:06:44.993 --> 00:06:49.334
So as a system admin, it's important to be
acquainted with these standard fields, so

119
00:06:49.334 --> 00:06:51.420
you know where to make the right changes.

120
00:06:51.420 --> 00:06:54.570
And you're not duplicating fields here.

121
00:06:54.570 --> 00:06:56.128
And then, if there was product related,

122
00:06:56.128 --> 00:06:57.872
you wanna have product
potential liability.

123
00:06:57.872 --> 00:07:03.060
If some of these don't pertain,
delete and remove these off the field.

124
00:07:03.060 --> 00:07:06.210
But, you do have to have a created by,
last modified by.

125
00:07:06.210 --> 00:07:10.110
And if you do need any custom links,
you can add them here.

126
00:07:10.110 --> 00:07:12.862
So at this page, we can see right
now that this is a new case.

127
00:07:12.862 --> 00:07:16.660
The priority is low and
this is my contact.

128
00:07:16.660 --> 00:07:22.540
Now, you wanna enable your support agents,
or your Salesforce users.

129
00:07:22.540 --> 00:07:26.590
To be able to quickly answer and
resolve these cases and

130
00:07:26.590 --> 00:07:30.610
you can set up what's called
knowledge within Salesforce, and

131
00:07:30.610 --> 00:07:35.700
have these pre-built out solutions
to help then determine, and

132
00:07:35.700 --> 00:07:39.900
provide recommendations
to resolving this case.

133
00:07:39.900 --> 00:07:44.700
So, I pulled over, we have solutions that
are built in, related to just this case.

134
00:07:44.700 --> 00:07:49.720
So, in this example, this is an issue
regarding to maintenance guidelines.

135
00:07:49.720 --> 00:07:54.455
So, I can go and view suggestions,
solutions or I can find solutions.

136
00:07:54.455 --> 00:07:59.856
So, it's gonna look at some certain key
words, it kinda recommends some for you,

137
00:07:59.856 --> 00:08:04.871
but if it doesn't find any match,
you wanna search within your solutions for

138
00:08:04.871 --> 00:08:08.135
a potential matches to provide for
the customer.

139
00:08:08.135 --> 00:08:09.520
Now, I'm wanna take it one step back.

140
00:08:09.520 --> 00:08:12.830
So, I'm going to find solution for
your cases, but

141
00:08:12.830 --> 00:08:16.350
before doing that you wanna make sure
you have solutions pre-built out.

142
00:08:16.350 --> 00:08:18.900
So, if you go over into
the solutions object,

143
00:08:20.530 --> 00:08:25.740
this is where you would create a list just
like any record of different solutions.

144
00:08:25.740 --> 00:08:30.050
And you can tag your solutions,
so this way they're easy to find,

145
00:08:30.050 --> 00:08:32.060
and they're searchable.

146
00:08:32.060 --> 00:08:35.220
So, right now, let's go into
list of all reviewed solutions,

147
00:08:35.220 --> 00:08:38.400
so you can see what this can look like.

148
00:08:38.400 --> 00:08:40.260
Using this industry that
we're in as an example,

149
00:08:40.260 --> 00:08:43.730
we see that we have GenWatt
installation services.

150
00:08:43.730 --> 00:08:48.780
So, this is a status, this is a solution
title that's gonna look to, and

151
00:08:48.780 --> 00:08:53.370
this is a solution details here,
that you could offer to your customer.

152
00:08:53.370 --> 00:08:57.970
So, you just pre, and very standard
field is either easy to make.

153
00:08:57.970 --> 00:09:01.000
I would provide a new solution and
this is something for

154
00:09:01.000 --> 00:09:04.650
your sales reps again to see and
have access to.

155
00:09:04.650 --> 00:09:06.160
Maybe they're searching,

156
00:09:06.160 --> 00:09:11.120
instead of searching around trying to find
the answer you have these pre-built out.

157
00:09:11.120 --> 00:09:15.792
And then, you can even add them
to your cases like we saw.

158
00:09:15.792 --> 00:09:18.900
So, as you're searching for
a solution, let's add one here.

159
00:09:23.115 --> 00:09:24.700
So, I'm gonna enter a keyword.

160
00:09:24.700 --> 00:09:29.680
And this is why you wanna be clear
as you're creating these solutions,

161
00:09:29.680 --> 00:09:31.242
let's enter service.

162
00:09:31.242 --> 00:09:37.120
This way you know how to quickly
find the right solutions.

163
00:09:37.120 --> 00:09:39.360
And this is for the end user.

164
00:09:39.360 --> 00:09:41.230
And so it gives us a few options,

165
00:09:41.230 --> 00:09:46.290
it tells us this is by typing in
service what maybe a possible solution.

166
00:09:46.290 --> 00:09:49.960
Let just go with the first one here,
it's related to service.

167
00:09:49.960 --> 00:09:54.030
And now you're gonna see the tie of
the solution to the case detail.

168
00:09:55.730 --> 00:10:01.330
Now, you can also straight directly
from Salesforce, you can send emails,

169
00:10:01.330 --> 00:10:05.110
now within sales you have activities,
you can generate emails there.

170
00:10:05.110 --> 00:10:08.604
But the difference with cases
is they store the email and

171
00:10:08.604 --> 00:10:10.694
that interaction with with you.

172
00:10:10.694 --> 00:10:16.020
Especially with the email to case and
the responses in a separate related list.

173
00:10:16.020 --> 00:10:20.910
And in the same list you can also
send an email directly to the client.

174
00:10:20.910 --> 00:10:26.070
And it will generate here and you can
pull in templates and add in files.

175
00:10:26.070 --> 00:10:31.650
So this way, you're keeping track of
that engagement towards closing this

176
00:10:31.650 --> 00:10:34.630
case, all within one record in Salesforce.

177
00:10:35.780 --> 00:10:39.720
Now also, with cases, just like
you could with account teams, and

178
00:10:39.720 --> 00:10:42.680
team selling, you can have case teams.

179
00:10:42.680 --> 00:10:47.120
So, maybe there's multiple people that
are involved in handling this case.

180
00:10:47.120 --> 00:10:49.940
So, Update Case Team Members, and

181
00:10:49.940 --> 00:10:55.378
prior to that you wanna drag this as
a related list into this object here.

182
00:10:55.378 --> 00:10:59.366
So, you're gonna look to
a list of all your users, and

183
00:10:59.366 --> 00:11:02.420
you have the access to even add contacts.

184
00:11:02.420 --> 00:11:06.061
That's one of the differences
between the case management and

185
00:11:06.061 --> 00:11:09.400
the case team members as
oppose to the account team.

186
00:11:09.400 --> 00:11:13.070
Because you can add contacts to this and
what is their role.

187
00:11:13.070 --> 00:11:17.610
Right now, we have not selected any
let me go into user and select myself.

188
00:11:18.660 --> 00:11:20.190
We don't have any roles set up, so

189
00:11:20.190 --> 00:11:24.240
you wanna set up what those roles
could be, and what their access is.

190
00:11:24.240 --> 00:11:28.420
And then,
if you had any pre built out case teams,

191
00:11:28.420 --> 00:11:33.210
then you can also have those groups built
out and search for those members here, and

192
00:11:33.210 --> 00:11:37.188
add groups of people one at a time
as opposed to individually.

193
00:11:37.188 --> 00:11:41.360
So, I'm gonna take a step back, and

194
00:11:41.360 --> 00:11:44.060
show you that sales force
also has a related case.

195
00:11:44.060 --> 00:11:45.150
So, this will show you and

196
00:11:45.150 --> 00:11:49.000
it's a related view, cases are related
pertaining to this client.

197
00:11:49.000 --> 00:11:52.876
So, you know how to quickly access,
and how you fixed a previous case,

198
00:11:52.876 --> 00:11:54.891
how you might be able to fix this one.

199
00:11:54.891 --> 00:11:59.849
So, this is all about helping the end
user, being able to quickly resolve cases

200
00:11:59.849 --> 00:12:04.440
because that's a common report
type needed in support centers.

201
00:12:04.440 --> 00:12:09.480
So, the time to complete cases is
crucial and being able to give them

202
00:12:09.480 --> 00:12:16.420
all the information they need to do so
themselves is what case management is for.

203
00:12:16.420 --> 00:12:18.590
And to really automate the process too.

204
00:12:18.590 --> 00:12:22.920
So, you have if we go into setup,
Case Assignment Rules and

205
00:12:22.920 --> 00:12:23.800
Case Escalation Rules.

206
00:12:23.800 --> 00:12:27.396
So, I'm gonna type into
cases in my quick find here.

207
00:12:27.396 --> 00:12:32.144
And we're gonna have Case Assignment Rules
located as a section,

208
00:12:32.144 --> 00:12:36.891
and within here, I can determine
based off any field in Salesforce

209
00:12:36.891 --> 00:12:42.760
the criteria you give it, who should
be the default owner of this case.

210
00:12:42.760 --> 00:12:45.730
So, right here we have
standard as an example.

211
00:12:45.730 --> 00:12:50.770
And right here, what we're telling this in
this role entry here, is anything that,

212
00:12:50.770 --> 00:12:55.920
where the SLA equals that this is a gold
or platinum customer, and the account

213
00:12:55.920 --> 00:13:00.775
type equals a customer, assign this to
myself, right now, being the only user.

214
00:13:00.775 --> 00:13:04.640
And in an org,
where you have multiple support agents

215
00:13:04.640 --> 00:13:08.140
that may be handling certain
territories or certain products or

216
00:13:08.140 --> 00:13:12.728
maybe a platinum customer,
you can start assigning it right here.

217
00:13:12.728 --> 00:13:15.010
So, you wanna make sure
that the fields exist, so

218
00:13:15.010 --> 00:13:17.790
that you can be able to
build this criteria.

219
00:13:17.790 --> 00:13:21.214
At this point,
you can establish how this get's assigned.

220
00:13:21.214 --> 00:13:25.882
So, once you've assigned it,
you've created this automated process,

221
00:13:25.882 --> 00:13:29.954
the second piece to go back, so
this will probably be in an email,

222
00:13:29.954 --> 00:13:33.460
it can be automated, and
assigned automatically.

223
00:13:33.460 --> 00:13:36.100
But it can also come in
through your webpage.

224
00:13:36.100 --> 00:13:39.221
So, similar to what we discussed
in another episode web to lead,

225
00:13:39.221 --> 00:13:40.826
you can also create a web to case.

226
00:13:40.826 --> 00:13:43.710
So, I'm gonna go back into my quick find.

227
00:13:46.431 --> 00:13:49.938
And show you that you can also
have the web to case over here.

228
00:13:49.938 --> 00:13:57.350
And go through I also wanna
show you the email to case.

229
00:13:57.350 --> 00:14:01.679
The same way that you can create the web
to lead, you can create the web to case.

230
00:14:01.679 --> 00:14:03.325
And you just, real simple,

231
00:14:03.325 --> 00:14:07.234
enter the leads that you want from
the left to right to select it, and

232
00:14:07.234 --> 00:14:11.640
it will generate the HTML code for
your webmaster to place onto the website.

233
00:14:11.640 --> 00:14:16.880
And the neat feature about that
is it will generate those cases

234
00:14:16.880 --> 00:14:20.810
automatically for you, and
then with the assignment rules you set up,

235
00:14:20.810 --> 00:14:23.710
your users will automatically
be notified of these cases.

236
00:14:25.670 --> 00:14:29.860
And then, the next piece would be the
Case Escalation Rules right under here.

237
00:14:32.580 --> 00:14:35.670
So, this is an example of
a Case Escalation Rule

238
00:14:35.670 --> 00:14:39.430
where if it starts moving up,
the priority equals high.

239
00:14:39.430 --> 00:14:41.950
Maybe needs to go to somebody higher up.

240
00:14:41.950 --> 00:14:43.910
The response time isn't soon enough.

241
00:14:44.920 --> 00:14:49.340
You have certain criteria you can set
up similar to your assignment rules of

242
00:14:49.340 --> 00:14:50.480
what happens next?

243
00:14:50.480 --> 00:14:55.816
Who does this get escalated to,
and what's the criteria set?

244
00:14:55.816 --> 00:14:58.346
So, in this one, the priority equals high,

245
00:14:58.346 --> 00:15:01.216
start moving this up in
the escalation rules here.

246
00:15:01.216 --> 00:15:05.312
And you can see how this can be move
of an automated process without

247
00:15:05.312 --> 00:15:09.100
having to talk to individuals,
and get the approvals.

248
00:15:09.100 --> 00:15:12.560
It's all sort of done
automatically in Salesforce.

249
00:15:14.550 --> 00:15:17.010
So, I'm gonna go back
into our case homepage.

250
00:15:19.163 --> 00:15:22.310
And we covered the creation of a case.

251
00:15:22.310 --> 00:15:25.360
We covered some of the options
to resolving the case.

252
00:15:25.360 --> 00:15:28.509
But where can you generate some of
these reports that Salesforce gives you

253
00:15:28.509 --> 00:15:29.079
out the box?

254
00:15:29.079 --> 00:15:31.450
You can do so from the homepage.

255
00:15:31.450 --> 00:15:35.410
But if you go in to do
reports object itself,

256
00:15:35.410 --> 00:15:41.320
Salesforce will give you a list of
folders with reports living inside.

257
00:15:41.320 --> 00:15:46.110
So, you wanna look for
the support report folder,

258
00:15:46.110 --> 00:15:51.070
and you can see this is
what Salesforce considers

259
00:15:51.070 --> 00:15:52.520
some reports that you might need.

260
00:15:52.520 --> 00:15:54.780
So, is it a history report?

261
00:15:54.780 --> 00:15:59.420
Let me see the relationship between my
solutions object with my cases object.

262
00:15:59.420 --> 00:16:04.142
I wanna see the relationship is that
the context rows within my cases, and

263
00:16:04.142 --> 00:16:09.166
since we went over to the events of the
cases, and the solutions, and how those

264
00:16:09.166 --> 00:16:13.919
two work together, this is an example
of how a cases with solution apart.

265
00:16:13.919 --> 00:16:19.090
So, showing you the type and
the cases that you have going for a given

266
00:16:19.090 --> 00:16:25.131
period of time, and if it's breaking
down the solution of created together.

267
00:16:25.131 --> 00:16:29.670
>> All right Felicia, great look and
demonstration of what we can do with cases

268
00:16:29.670 --> 00:16:33.940
within Salesforce, how we can
provide that service and support.

269
00:16:33.940 --> 00:16:34.950
So, we appreciate that.

270
00:16:34.950 --> 00:16:37.300
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

271
00:16:37.300 --> 00:16:40.470
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

272
00:16:40.470 --> 00:16:41.430
>> I'm Felicia Duarte.

273
00:16:41.430 --> 00:16:46.765
>> And we'll see you next time.

274
00:16:46.765 --> 00:16:49.694
[MUSIC]

275
00:16:49.694 --> 00:16:52.010
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Felicia and Mike discuss activities and chatter. They demonstrate tasks and events, and explain the difference between the two. They also discuss Chatter feed and notifications.
episodes.title: Activities and Chatter
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.434
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.434 --> 00:00:06.704
I'm your host [INAUDIBLE]

3
00:00:06.704 --> 00:00:08.242
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.242 --> 00:00:12.343
You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.343 --> 00:00:15.090
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.380 --> 00:00:17.760
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and

7
00:00:17.760 --> 00:00:21.210
today we're doing our
Salesforce Certified Administrator.

8
00:00:21.210 --> 00:00:25.470
And in this episode we're going to be
looking at activities and chatter.

9
00:00:25.470 --> 00:00:28.940
And here to chat with us about
chatter is Ms. Felicia Duarte.

10
00:00:28.940 --> 00:00:29.960
Welcome back, Felicia.

11
00:00:29.960 --> 00:00:30.830
>> Thank you.

12
00:00:30.830 --> 00:00:34.770
So on this episode today, I'm going
to talk to activities and chatter.

13
00:00:34.770 --> 00:00:35.900
Now we've covered,

14
00:00:35.900 --> 00:00:40.080
in our other episodes, most of the larger
pieces that are part of the exam.

15
00:00:40.080 --> 00:00:43.534
Activities account for
3% of the test questions and

16
00:00:43.534 --> 00:00:45.870
chatter accounts for a small 1%.

17
00:00:45.870 --> 00:00:49.355
But again they all add up, so
it's good to know everything and

18
00:00:49.355 --> 00:00:52.360
it's good to know the areas you might not
know so much, where you're weaker in, so

19
00:00:52.360 --> 00:00:54.700
at least you get those questions right.

20
00:00:54.700 --> 00:00:58.130
Every question and
right answer counts on this exam.

21
00:00:58.130 --> 00:00:59.950
So let's start with activities.

22
00:00:59.950 --> 00:01:01.410
What is an activity?

23
00:01:01.410 --> 00:01:03.030
An activity holds two things.

24
00:01:03.030 --> 00:01:04.100
You can have your events.

25
00:01:04.100 --> 00:01:06.110
And then you can have your task.

26
00:01:06.110 --> 00:01:09.360
Now the difference
between the two is events

27
00:01:09.360 --> 00:01:13.580
will always have a start time and
an end time.

28
00:01:13.580 --> 00:01:15.940
Think of your events as conferences,

29
00:01:15.940 --> 00:01:19.880
meetings, anything with a start date and
end date.

30
00:01:19.880 --> 00:01:24.600
And then your task, which we'll get in to,
can be anything from logging a call

31
00:01:24.600 --> 00:01:28.195
to maybe a follow-up
task that you need to do.

32
00:01:28.195 --> 00:01:30.450
Follow-up with an email,
make a phone call.

33
00:01:30.450 --> 00:01:32.570
So what we'll go through some of those.

34
00:01:32.570 --> 00:01:35.600
So let's navigate through
within Salesforce and

35
00:01:35.600 --> 00:01:38.530
get over into the activities
from your home page.

36
00:01:38.530 --> 00:01:41.590
So right now we're
looking at the home page.

37
00:01:41.590 --> 00:01:46.300
You can see a list of your calendar
which will hold your events,

38
00:01:46.300 --> 00:01:48.020
your tasks, and items to approve.

39
00:01:48.020 --> 00:01:50.810
So let's start with meetings.

40
00:01:50.810 --> 00:01:54.470
So aside from the activities of tasks and
events,

41
00:01:54.470 --> 00:01:57.910
you can schedule meetings and
request meetings.

42
00:01:57.910 --> 00:01:59.792
Now meetings can be sent out,

43
00:01:59.792 --> 00:02:04.086
meeting requests within Salesforce
can be sent out to your leads and

44
00:02:04.086 --> 00:02:08.251
contacts within Salesforce,
as well as your Salesforce users.

45
00:02:08.251 --> 00:02:14.643
So if we hit, from your home page,
new meeting request and select here.

46
00:02:16.098 --> 00:02:19.640
This is a pretty neat feature
that Salesforce has out the box.

47
00:02:19.640 --> 00:02:24.179
You can add invitees and
you can select from here, search for

48
00:02:24.179 --> 00:02:27.120
existing users, leads and contacts.

49
00:02:27.120 --> 00:02:30.278
As long as they already
exist within Salesforce.

50
00:02:30.278 --> 00:02:31.790
So once you select the users,

51
00:02:31.790 --> 00:02:36.302
you can enter a subject line because
you'll be sending it via an email.

52
00:02:36.302 --> 00:02:40.490
A where, if you have a place,
you can leave it as TBD.

53
00:02:40.490 --> 00:02:42.280
And then, propose meeting time.

54
00:02:42.280 --> 00:02:44.460
So I like this feature of Salesforce.

55
00:02:44.460 --> 00:02:50.200
You can let Salesforce look within your
calendar to suggest meeting times or

56
00:02:50.200 --> 00:02:52.390
you can pick five times slots.

57
00:02:52.390 --> 00:02:54.277
So let's just select a few.

58
00:02:55.437 --> 00:03:01.010
On these dates here and if I selected too
many, I'm gonna hit okay, the max is five.

59
00:03:01.010 --> 00:03:02.890
And then set the duration.

60
00:03:02.890 --> 00:03:08.200
So is it for one hour, two hours, you
can go all the way up to eight hours and

61
00:03:08.200 --> 00:03:12.940
it will block out on that time frame for
you within your Salesforce calendar.

62
00:03:12.940 --> 00:03:15.940
And we're gonna suggest these times and
hit next.

63
00:03:15.940 --> 00:03:18.290
I'm gonna select See
a sample meeting request so

64
00:03:18.290 --> 00:03:19.720
you can see what that would look like.

65
00:03:21.330 --> 00:03:25.689
Later on, I'll talk to adding and
making this enable to add your logo here.

66
00:03:25.689 --> 00:03:28.645
But once you do,
you can see the five time slots or

67
00:03:28.645 --> 00:03:30.967
in this case six time slots selected.

68
00:03:30.967 --> 00:03:32.781
And this is what the email
would look like.

69
00:03:32.781 --> 00:03:35.647
They'd get an email with
the meeting request.

70
00:03:35.647 --> 00:03:37.063
From who.

71
00:03:37.063 --> 00:03:39.351
What the subject is that you selected.

72
00:03:39.351 --> 00:03:43.038
The who, the when,
the duration, and where.

73
00:03:43.038 --> 00:03:45.291
And then, your user or your lead or

74
00:03:45.291 --> 00:03:51.095
your contact has the option of selecting
the time frame that works best with them.

75
00:03:51.095 --> 00:03:53.985
And then that will block out to
your calendar within Salesforce.

76
00:03:53.985 --> 00:03:57.115
It's a really neat feature,
make sure you know it.

77
00:03:57.115 --> 00:03:58.975
Test it, try it out yourself.

78
00:03:59.975 --> 00:04:03.285
Again, I suggest always testing
things out all the way through so

79
00:04:03.285 --> 00:04:05.425
you fully understand the concept.

80
00:04:05.425 --> 00:04:08.950
So when you see a question,
you know how to answer it on the exam.

81
00:04:08.950 --> 00:04:12.210
And then once I select Next,
we went through this, sorry,

82
00:04:12.210 --> 00:04:15.010
we went through this piece of
the adding of the to and the from.

83
00:04:15.010 --> 00:04:17.270
This is just gonna show you
what that would look like.

84
00:04:17.270 --> 00:04:18.950
So you got the subject and the where.

85
00:04:18.950 --> 00:04:21.910
And then if you need to make any
previous changes, you can go ahead and

86
00:04:21.910 --> 00:04:24.250
do so or add an additional message.

87
00:04:24.250 --> 00:04:27.150
But once that's all said and
done, this is showing up.

88
00:04:27.150 --> 00:04:29.520
These are required fields,
because I didn't select any invitee or

89
00:04:29.520 --> 00:04:31.080
subject at that time.

90
00:04:31.080 --> 00:04:32.470
And then send it out.

91
00:04:32.470 --> 00:04:35.570
So it's a really neat
feature that you have.

92
00:04:35.570 --> 00:04:38.770
From your home page,
let's take a look into your calendar.

93
00:04:38.770 --> 00:04:43.980
So right now we're looking at calendar,
we're looking at a single user view.

94
00:04:43.980 --> 00:04:47.470
If I select this,
you can have a multi-user view.

95
00:04:47.470 --> 00:04:52.266
And you can see everyone within
the Salesforce org That you have access to

96
00:04:52.266 --> 00:04:53.922
seeing their calendar.

97
00:04:53.922 --> 00:04:56.188
So you can see that right now,
I'm looking at a one day view.

98
00:04:56.188 --> 00:05:00.715
So hour by hour, but also have the option
of seeing it as a weekly view, or

99
00:05:00.715 --> 00:05:02.140
as a monthly view.

100
00:05:02.140 --> 00:05:04.006
You can see how this changes here.

101
00:05:04.006 --> 00:05:06.565
There's a few different view
settings that you can see so

102
00:05:06.565 --> 00:05:08.278
if you want to see it by week and month.

103
00:05:08.278 --> 00:05:12.970
But you can also see it within
these values that you choose.

104
00:05:12.970 --> 00:05:15.510
If you're working with an org or
setting up an org,

105
00:05:15.510 --> 00:05:20.250
you have over a 100 employees, I'm sure
you don't associate with all of them.

106
00:05:20.250 --> 00:05:24.630
I would break it up into different
views that matters to you.

107
00:05:24.630 --> 00:05:27.000
And you can see the views differently.

108
00:05:28.100 --> 00:05:30.610
From here it's more of a task item view.

109
00:05:30.610 --> 00:05:35.710
And this will show all your tasks and
events associated with these users here.

110

Invitations, all this is made here.
