00:19:04.510 --> 00:19:09.572
But for
the feed tracking you're gonna come here.

340
00:19:09.572 --> 00:19:14.172
And this is where you can identify what
information is important to track as

341
00:19:14.172 --> 00:19:18.640
far as field changes within that
tracking page on your home page here.

342
00:19:18.640 --> 00:19:23.131
So I've had requests where
it's not important to track

343
00:19:23.131 --> 00:19:26.101
the owner as it is to track the stage.

344
00:19:26.101 --> 00:19:31.057
And this is per object here, and this
will show you off the bat, as you go in,

345
00:19:31.057 --> 00:19:33.090
what am I tracking currently?

346
00:19:34.130 --> 00:19:38.300
I've had clients ask me to troubleshoot
for them, I'm coming on to my homepage and

347
00:19:38.300 --> 00:19:42.390
I'm seeing information that's tracked for
this object and why am I seeing this.

348
00:19:42.390 --> 00:19:46.746
And sometimes they're already frustrated
cuz if you have it expanded it's gonna

349
00:19:46.746 --> 00:19:48.019
take up your full page.

350
00:19:48.019 --> 00:19:53.113
So, you'd navigate to feed tracking and
you go into the object and you can see,

351
00:19:53.113 --> 00:19:58.603
aha, case we're looking at two fields
priority, maybe it's not important to see.

352
00:19:58.603 --> 00:20:01.290
So, that's where you navigate for there.

353
00:20:01.290 --> 00:20:07.770
But, let's get into the profile, and
what you can see, what you can do.

354
00:20:07.770 --> 00:20:11.845
So, you can have, again, this is your
feed base, which we went over, but

355
00:20:11.845 --> 00:20:14.972
you can have an overview, and
you can have this per user.

356
00:20:14.972 --> 00:20:19.070
So again, like I mentioned,
your similar to like a social media.

357
00:20:19.070 --> 00:20:20.980
You have your contact information,

358
00:20:20.980 --> 00:20:24.330
you can make any other changes
that you want to add here.

359
00:20:24.330 --> 00:20:31.130
What's your contribution to any of
these chat-like features that we have.

360
00:20:31.130 --> 00:20:32.695
What do you know about, what's,

361
00:20:32.695 --> 00:20:37.980
basic contact information about yourself
that you wanna share with other users.

362
00:20:37.980 --> 00:20:40.270
I've seen it used in
a lot of creative ways.

363
00:20:40.270 --> 00:20:44.129
And as a partner of Salesforce,
we have a partner.

364
00:20:44.129 --> 00:20:51.010
We have a place where we can go to to open
different folders and files and groups.

365
00:20:51.010 --> 00:20:52.880
So maybe you can have groups created.

366
00:20:52.880 --> 00:20:56.596
And as you see to the top right,
right now it created a group for

367
00:20:56.596 --> 00:20:59.682
all cloud C when I created
my user name and profile.

368
00:20:59.682 --> 00:21:01.508
But I can add groups here and

369
00:21:01.508 --> 00:21:06.530
I can add groups as a system admin from
my sales users and marketing users.

370
00:21:06.530 --> 00:21:09.860
And I can place appropriate people
here and what the great thing is,

371
00:21:09.860 --> 00:21:12.310
is we can all share files.

372
00:21:12.310 --> 00:21:15.780
And those are documents, and
they don't have to be related

373
00:21:15.780 --> 00:21:18.960
specifically to a record,
they can just live within that group.

374
00:21:18.960 --> 00:21:23.130
Maybe it's PowerPoint presentations or
marketing material that you don't want,

375
00:21:23.130 --> 00:21:27.580
and it's a private group that
you don't want any other

376
00:21:27.580 --> 00:21:30.260
member not a part of that group to see.

377
00:21:30.260 --> 00:21:32.724
So right now we're looking
in the example all cloud c.

378
00:21:32.724 --> 00:21:36.753
So this is pulling from the company name
but here are some of the settings you can

379
00:21:36.753 --> 00:21:39.460
make in configurations
within the group settings.

380
00:21:41.760 --> 00:21:45.420
So the name, the description and
the access level.

381
00:21:45.420 --> 00:21:51.041
So is this a public group Is it
a private group, so in that example it's

382
00:21:51.041 --> 00:21:56.495
locked in a sales group, and
marketing group, and support group.

383
00:21:56.495 --> 00:21:58.510
And so these are your options here.

384
00:21:58.510 --> 00:22:02.611
So I'm gonna, if you want this open
you can read some more later, but

385
00:22:02.611 --> 00:22:07.303
you can see how it could be useful to kind
of place members in different groups.

386
00:22:07.303 --> 00:22:13.260
And you can invite people and add members
and share records if it's accessible.

387
00:22:13.260 --> 00:22:16.230
And see the engagement, create reports.

388
00:22:16.230 --> 00:22:20.870
You can email from here and add more info
but it's a great way to engage with other

389
00:22:20.870 --> 00:22:25.661
users in Salesforce and share information
to help each other be more productive.

390
00:22:25.661 --> 00:22:31.220
So one other point too is as I'm
getting through this is so posting.

391
00:22:31.220 --> 00:22:35.170
So we utilize it as
a product management tool

392
00:22:35.170 --> 00:22:37.580
as we're going through
a custom object name project.

393
00:22:37.580 --> 00:22:40.040
So if you're going through
your opportunities

394
00:22:40.040 --> 00:22:45.500
let's use the example as a sales manager
I'm back at this opportunity here.

395
00:22:45.500 --> 00:22:47.460
And we have chatter enabled.

396
00:22:47.460 --> 00:22:52.710
I can at to the owner of the record or
at any user, and simply say.

397
00:22:52.710 --> 00:22:55.038
I think only myself will show.

398
00:22:55.038 --> 00:22:56.810
So similar to social media.

399
00:22:58.985 --> 00:23:03.415
Where are we on closing this deal,
or if it was a case,

400
00:23:03.415 --> 00:23:07.264
what's the case status, what's an update?

401
00:23:07.264 --> 00:23:10.945
And anyone who has access to see
the record can pull down the feed and

402
00:23:10.945 --> 00:23:13.848
see the communication
between everyone else here.

403
00:23:13.848 --> 00:23:18.260
So, attach a file if you think
that's gonna be helpful.

404
00:23:18.260 --> 00:23:20.520
So it's a pretty productive tool.

405
00:23:20.520 --> 00:23:23.320
And you can create polls and add topics.

406
00:23:23.320 --> 00:23:29.230
So if the add topics relating to closing
deals or solutions, I can add topics here.

407
00:23:29.230 --> 00:23:35.098
And let's say, open opportunities.

408
00:23:38.392 --> 00:23:41.685
And now you can see there's
a topic I wanted to add

409
00:23:41.685 --> 00:23:45.630
to it called Open Opportunity,
similar to tags.

410
00:23:45.630 --> 00:23:50.180
And now when I click this one that
I created you can see the topics

411
00:23:50.180 --> 00:23:54.550
within Chatter and
the feed related to that topic.

412
00:23:56.290 --> 00:23:59.137
>> All right Felicia,
great look there at some of the,

413
00:23:59.137 --> 00:24:02.049
almost like the social
capabilities of sales force,

414
00:24:02.049 --> 00:24:05.949
you have the ability to work with
events different acts of activities.

415
00:24:05.949 --> 00:24:08.518
You got events, and
task that we can work with.

416
00:24:08.518 --> 00:24:12.817
And in the whole chatter,
where we can really collaborate with our

417
00:24:12.817 --> 00:24:16.610
co-workers as well as customers,
SalesForce.

418
00:24:16.610 --> 00:24:17.782
So we appreciate that, great look there.

419
00:24:17.782 --> 00:24:21.110
I hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

420
00:24:21.110 --> 00:24:22.440
Signing off for ITPro.TV.

421
00:24:22.440 --> 00:24:24.011
I've been your host, Mick Rodrick.

422
00:24:24.011 --> 00:24:25.342
>> I'm Felicia Duarte.

423
00:24:25.342 --> 00:24:26.877
>> And we'll see you next time.

424
00:24:26.877 --> 00:24:33.366
[MUSIC]

425
00:24:33.366 --> 00:24:35.845
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Felicia and Mike demonstrate different ways to import, upload and transfer data in Salesforce. They look at data loaders and backing up data.
episodes.title: Data Management and Data Loaders
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.317
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.317 --> 00:00:02.031
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.031 --> 00:00:06.405
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.405 --> 00:00:08.277
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.277 --> 00:00:12.376
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.376 --> 00:00:16.049
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.049 --> 00:00:17.513
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and

8
00:00:17.513 --> 00:00:20.509
today we're doing our
Salesforce Certified Administrator.

9
00:00:20.509 --> 00:00:24.897
And in this episode, we're going to be
taking a look at data management and

10
00:00:24.897 --> 00:00:25.813
data loaders.

11
00:00:25.813 --> 00:00:29.964
And here to load us up with all kinds of
useful information is Miss Felicia Duarte.

12
00:00:29.964 --> 00:00:31.108
Welcome back, Felicia.

13
00:00:31.108 --> 00:00:32.266
>> Great, thank you.

14
00:00:32.266 --> 00:00:35.749
So in this episode,
I want to cover data loaders and

15
00:00:35.749 --> 00:00:38.700
data management within Salesforce.

16
00:00:38.700 --> 00:00:41.750
So this holds 9% weight
within the exam itself.

17
00:00:41.750 --> 00:00:46.142
So I would make sure to do a test import,
make sure you're completely aware.

18
00:00:46.142 --> 00:00:50.538
Troubleshoot some issues on what you can
do within Salesforce regarding your data.

19
00:00:50.538 --> 00:00:54.910
Regarding existing data,
importing new data, upserting,

20
00:00:54.910 --> 00:00:58.870
updating data within Salesforce,
cleaning out data.

21
00:00:58.870 --> 00:01:02.170
So those are some of the goals and
topics of this episode today.

22
00:01:02.170 --> 00:01:04.265
And we're gonna start with your homepage.

23
00:01:04.265 --> 00:01:06.515
So I'm gonna navigate over here.

24
00:01:06.515 --> 00:01:11.268
And how to import records in
different places within Salesforce?

25
00:01:11.268 --> 00:01:14.011
So as you saw in some of
the previous episodes.

26
00:01:14.011 --> 00:01:16.881
Every time you go into an object,
standard object,

27
00:01:16.881 --> 00:01:19.330
or even a custom object within Salesforce.

28
00:01:19.330 --> 00:01:22.990
You have options to run reports,
recent accounts, but

29
00:01:22.990 --> 00:01:25.220
you'll see a section here called Tools.

30
00:01:25.220 --> 00:01:29.300
Now in this section here,
they vary by a standard object to object.

31
00:01:29.300 --> 00:01:32.530
But for the main ones like accounts,
and contacts, and

32
00:01:32.530 --> 00:01:36.018
leads, you're gonna see
the options to run imports.

33
00:01:36.018 --> 00:01:40.094
Now we're in the Account object here so
[INAUDIBLE] option to run Import for

34
00:01:40.094 --> 00:01:41.746
both accounts and contacts.

35
00:01:41.746 --> 00:01:47.898
Now you can certainly run your imports and
add records from here.

36
00:01:47.898 --> 00:01:51.280
And so we're gonna start here just
to show you one way to do so.

37
00:01:52.755 --> 00:01:58.070
So the very first step, as an admin I'm
sure you've run in to this issue before.

38
00:01:58.070 --> 00:02:00.318
You're gonna want a clean house.

39
00:02:00.318 --> 00:02:02.178
So make sure your data is clean.

40
00:02:02.178 --> 00:02:04.528
Because you don't wanna
push in dirty data.

41
00:02:04.528 --> 00:02:08.517
You wanna check to make sure you
don't have any duplicate data.

42
00:02:08.517 --> 00:02:11.327
If you're just gonna push in from scratch

43
00:02:11.327 --> 00:02:14.507
that's probably the best way when
you're working with a new org.

44
00:02:14.507 --> 00:02:16.461
Check the spreadsheet first.

45
00:02:16.461 --> 00:02:21.170
Now, I'm gonna go through and troubleshoot
through some common scenarios that I

46
00:02:21.170 --> 00:02:23.480
see often as I'm doing import records.

47
00:02:23.480 --> 00:02:27.380
But this data import wizard that
Salesforce gives you out of the boxes

48
00:02:27.380 --> 00:02:28.160
is great.

49
00:02:28.160 --> 00:02:29.060
It's easy to do.

50
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:31.350
It's easy to understand.

51
00:02:31.350 --> 00:02:34.280
If you're not working
with large sets of data,

52
00:02:34.280 --> 00:02:37.380
because you can only do
50,000 records at a time.

53
00:02:37.380 --> 00:02:40.274
If we're going over 100,000 and 50,000,

54
00:02:40.274 --> 00:02:44.080
you're gonna wanna break that up if
you're still gonna utilize this way.

55
00:02:44.080 --> 00:02:47.220
But there are other
alternatives to importing data.

56
00:02:47.220 --> 00:02:50.785
So let's launch the wizard and
go through the steps.

57
00:02:50.785 --> 00:02:54.332
So we can see here,
Prepare your data for import.

58
00:02:54.332 --> 00:02:57.125
So if we're gonna import object by object,

59
00:02:57.125 --> 00:03:00.077
you can't import multiple
objects at a time.

60
00:03:00.077 --> 00:03:04.900
So if you're gonna import contacts,
you wanna import the accounts first.

61
00:03:04.900 --> 00:03:09.784
Because you're gonna wanna pull out
the account's Salesforce ID in order to

62
00:03:09.784 --> 00:03:13.220
associate the contact with that account.

63
00:03:13.220 --> 00:03:15.832
So we're gonna start with
something real simple like leads.

64
00:03:15.832 --> 00:03:19.248
Leads is probably one of the easiest
things to import because there's no

65
00:03:19.248 --> 00:03:19.978
association.

66
00:03:19.978 --> 00:03:26.232
There's no separate objects or
database tables to associate it to.

67
00:03:26.232 --> 00:03:28.433
So prepare your data.

68
00:03:28.433 --> 00:03:30.654
Look at what the required
fields are first.

69
00:03:30.654 --> 00:03:32.830
Because that's one step.

70
00:03:32.830 --> 00:03:38.380
The data, the import file will not
pass if there are certain validations.

71
00:03:38.380 --> 00:03:44.919
Or if there are required fields that
are not included in your CSV columns.

72
00:03:44.919 --> 00:03:48.082
So we're gonna go ahead and
launch the wizard here.

73
00:03:48.082 --> 00:03:53.335
And if you need help importing,
recheck this video, watch some videos.

74
00:03:53.335 --> 00:03:55.252
Get a developer account,

75
00:03:55.252 --> 00:04:00.754
test out some records yourself before
you do a final push into production.

76
00:04:00.754 --> 00:04:05.010
Or we'll create a sandbox environment,
your testing environment,

77
00:04:05.010 --> 00:04:06.967
to play with the testing there.

78
00:04:06.967 --> 00:04:11.930
If you have existing data and
your org is already being used.

79
00:04:11.930 --> 00:04:14.589
So, let's launch the wizard, and

80
00:04:14.589 --> 00:04:19.115
you can see here they give you
some positive encouragement.

81
00:04:19.115 --> 00:04:19.855
Let's do this.

82
00:04:19.855 --> 00:04:22.346
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And you have the choice.

83
00:04:22.346 --> 00:04:23.490
It kinda walks you through.

84
00:04:23.490 --> 00:04:25.890
It's nice,
cuz it walks you through these prompts.

85
00:04:25.890 --> 00:04:27.950
So, what's the object
you wanna start with?

86
00:04:27.950 --> 00:04:29.849
Keeps it real simple, Leads.

87
00:04:29.849 --> 00:04:31.193
What do you wanna do?

88
00:04:31.193 --> 00:04:34.090
You give it a second,
I wanna add new records,

89
00:04:34.090 --> 00:04:36.850
or I wanna make update
to existing records.

90
00:04:38.740 --> 00:04:39.240
Let's stick here.

91
00:04:39.240 --> 00:04:43.040
If you wanna update existing records,
you wanna pull out and

92
00:04:43.040 --> 00:04:46.420
use what Salesforce calls
our Salesforce unique ID.

93
00:04:46.420 --> 00:04:49.801
Every record in Salesforce
has a Salesforce ID.

94
00:04:49.801 --> 00:04:54.265
And I believe it's a 15,
and I would check on that,

95
00:04:54.265 --> 00:04:59.539
it's a 15 digit number that
you want to use, alphanumeric.

96
00:04:59.539 --> 00:05:03.500
That's unique to the record to
go back in and make changes to.

97
00:05:03.500 --> 00:05:06.840
So right now, we're just gonna keep
it simple and do Add New Records, but

98
00:05:06.840 --> 00:05:07.580
you can do both.

99
00:05:07.580 --> 00:05:08.896
What we consider an upsert.

100
00:05:08.896 --> 00:05:13.066
So add new records and
update existing records.

101
00:05:13.066 --> 00:05:16.669
So these are your three options
here using this wizard.

102
00:05:17.977 --> 00:05:23.593
Now, with other areas to import you
can also do mass deletes or changes.

103
00:05:23.593 --> 00:05:25.655
But within this wizard here,

104
00:05:25.655 --> 00:05:30.858
if you're only looking to do those
three options, you can do so from here.

105
00:05:30.858 --> 00:05:34.037
So if we're going to match records and
add new records,

106
00:05:34.037 --> 00:05:37.070
are you matching with a name or email?

107
00:05:37.070 --> 00:05:39.239
Do you need to assign new
leads to this source?

108
00:05:41.110 --> 00:05:42.301
So these are your source options here.

109
00:05:42.301 --> 00:05:43.971
So it's going to be based off
the fields that you have.

110
00:05:43.971 --> 00:05:45.832
We're gonna keep it at none, and

111
00:05:45.832 --> 00:05:49.497
[INAUDIBLE] assigned all leads
using any of the assignment rules.

112
00:05:49.497 --> 00:05:52.981
So it's gonna look to the assignment
rules, but we're gonna select None, and

113
00:05:52.981 --> 00:05:54.530
keep it real simple.

114
00:05:54.530 --> 00:05:56.700
And then drag your CSV files here.

115
00:05:56.700 --> 00:06:01.041
So I'm gonna go into This file, and

116
00:06:01.041 --> 00:06:04.510
I have it already ready, and
before I do that, let's open it up.

117
00:06:06.390 --> 00:06:09.242
So, we're gonna map, and
I'm gonna take it a step back,

118
00:06:09.242 --> 00:06:11.353
cuz I have this for
accounts and not leads.

119
00:06:11.353 --> 00:06:13.700
[LAUGH] So, I'm gonna take it a step back.

120
00:06:13.700 --> 00:06:16.971
And you certainly wanna
double check your work.

121
00:06:16.971 --> 00:06:21.210
[LAUGH] So, this is a good example, that
you're importing into the right object.

122
00:06:21.210 --> 00:06:22.450
Otherwise you're going back.

123
00:06:22.450 --> 00:06:24.580
And you're gonna get a,
I would've done it this way.

124
00:06:24.580 --> 00:06:25.660
I'm gonna not find a mapping.

125
00:06:25.660 --> 00:06:28.090
I'm gonna get an error.

126
00:06:28.090 --> 00:06:32.000
And that will kind of alert me that,
hey you're mapping to the wrong objects.

127
00:06:32.000 --> 00:06:38.820
So I like that I can go back and from the
same page select Accounts and Contacts.

128
00:06:38.820 --> 00:06:43.160
And then we're gonna do Add New Records,
and it's gonna follow the same prompts.

129
00:06:43.160 --> 00:06:44.780
How do you wanna match your contact?

130
00:06:44.780 --> 00:06:45.780
By name.

131
00:06:45.780 --> 00:06:46.362
Match account?

132
00:06:46.362 --> 00:06:48.856
By name and site, or select None.

133
00:06:48.856 --> 00:06:51.430
And do we wanna trigger any workflows?

134
00:06:51.430 --> 00:06:57.446
We don't have any active workflows
at the time, or processes.

135
00:06:57.446 --> 00:07:01.090
And we don't need to assign all contacts
to any campaigns at this point.

136
00:07:01.090 --> 00:07:03.610
We simply just want to add accounts.

137
00:07:03.610 --> 00:07:06.537
So we'll do the same thing and drag but

138
00:07:06.537 --> 00:07:11.768
lets take a look at this file and
let's go into, I'm gonna copy this

139
00:07:16.322 --> 00:07:23.430
And I'm going to try to navigate back
into the account object to show you.

140
00:07:23.430 --> 00:07:28.265
So this is a second tab and just to show
you the mapping and how everything looks.

141
00:07:28.265 --> 00:07:32.348
So we need to have an account name,
which we do.

142
00:07:32.348 --> 00:07:34.185
And I pulled in some of the fields here.

143
00:07:34.185 --> 00:07:36.390
So account number, it's a number field.

144
00:07:36.390 --> 00:07:37.880
Make sure that the field types map.

145
00:07:37.880 --> 00:07:38.834
If it's a currency,

146
00:07:38.834 --> 00:07:42.071
it has to be a currency amount with
the decimal points that you selected.

147
00:07:42.071 --> 00:07:46.720
If it's a pick list value,
it has to be spelled accurately,

148
00:07:46.720 --> 00:07:51.017
the value that exists and
is active within Salesforce.

149
00:07:51.017 --> 00:07:52.559
So, we're talking one record.

150
00:07:52.559 --> 00:07:53.568
This is gonna be simple.

151
00:07:53.568 --> 00:07:56.821
But when you're working with
thousands of records at a time,

152
00:07:56.821 --> 00:07:59.272
you can't go in individually and
check that.

153
00:07:59.272 --> 00:08:03.670
So, I would just do Sort Filters,
really know your Excel.

154
00:08:03.670 --> 00:08:08.801
How to make changes, how to check and
make sure that those values are separated.

155
00:08:08.801 --> 00:08:13.447
And if you find a value within your
spreadsheet that doesn't exist as a value

156
00:08:13.447 --> 00:08:14.475
in Salesforce.

157
00:08:14.475 --> 00:08:18.985
You want to go in and either delete and
change that value before importing.

158
00:08:18.985 --> 00:08:23.960
Or you want to go back into Salesforce and
add that value to that field.

159
00:08:23.960 --> 00:08:29.340
Another common issue that we
come across is when you're

160
00:08:29.340 --> 00:08:33.900
pulling in or bringing in data from
another database is the streets.

161
00:08:33.900 --> 00:08:37.960
So sometimes it's all in one field so
you need to break that down.

162
00:08:37.960 --> 00:08:42.550
Salesforce has it broken down into
the street, city, zip, country.

163
00:08:42.550 --> 00:08:44.629
So you wanna make sure that is split up,

164
00:08:44.629 --> 00:08:48.605
if it's not you wanna utilize Excel
to split them into different columns.

165
00:08:48.605 --> 00:08:52.746
And then, again, number of fields,
make sure they're in the right category.

166
00:08:52.746 --> 00:08:56.372
Website's pretty simple and
then everything else.

167
00:08:56.372 --> 00:08:59.230
I don't necessarily need
to have every column here.

168
00:08:59.230 --> 00:09:02.693
I can just import the data
that I wanna import.

169
00:09:02.693 --> 00:09:06.542
So I can do three different imports at
different times just to update the type or

170
00:09:06.542 --> 00:09:07.722
fields individually.

171
00:09:07.722 --> 00:09:10.867
And doesn't have to be all
the fields as a whole.

172
00:09:10.867 --> 00:09:13.440
So right now we're just
gonna do the accounts.

173
00:09:13.440 --> 00:09:19.729
Everything looks good, so I'm going
to go back and drop that over Here.

174
00:09:31.011 --> 00:09:35.132
So the check box is green,
it is an accurate CSV file, so

175
00:09:35.132 --> 00:09:38.140
make sure to save as a CSV file.

176
00:09:38.140 --> 00:09:40.181
And we're just gonna follow
the prompts and hit Next.

177
00:09:43.695 --> 00:09:49.658
So if the column names are named in
the exact same format as the field's name,

178
00:09:49.658 --> 00:09:51.970
it's gonna find you a match.

179
00:09:51.970 --> 00:09:55.420
So it always makes it easier to have
the columns ready to go and named.

180
00:09:55.420 --> 00:09:57.530
But if not, that's fine.

181
00:09:57.530 --> 00:10:03.265
If I wanted to map the account
name to another field.

182
00:10:03.265 --> 00:10:06.399
Or [LAUGH] I start making custom fields
and they're a little bit different,

183
00:10:06.399 --> 00:10:07.204
that's okay too.

184
00:10:07.204 --> 00:10:09.726
You can select the unmapped.

185
00:10:09.726 --> 00:10:11.858
Go into the runs and select Map.

186
00:10:11.858 --> 00:10:15.375
And you can make changes and then let it
know which one you want to map it to.

187
00:10:15.375 --> 00:10:19.251
So we're looking at Revenue,
it says Revenue in my column,

188
00:10:19.251 --> 00:10:22.524
but that needs to actually
bill to annual revenue.

189
00:10:22.524 --> 00:10:23.992
Which is this one here.

190
00:10:23.992 --> 00:10:26.649
So you can kind of see how easy
it is to make those changes.

191
00:10:26.649 --> 00:10:29.980
Real simple,
otherwise if it was to just push it in,

192
00:10:29.980 --> 00:10:32.342
it would be an unsuccessful import.

193
00:10:32.342 --> 00:10:40.780
And then Billing Zip, so it's
Billing Zip Postal Code, and map it there.

194
00:10:40.780 --> 00:10:41.540
And then it looks good.

195
00:10:41.540 --> 00:10:42.530
Everything looks good.

196
00:10:42.530 --> 00:10:43.420
Everything's mapped.

197
00:10:43.420 --> 00:10:47.090
This will show you right here
what's the Salesforce object.

198
00:10:47.090 --> 00:10:49.490
What's the header in my CSV file?

199
00:10:49.490 --> 00:10:52.150
And then what's this going to look
like once it actually pushes over?

200
00:10:52.150 --> 00:10:55.823
So I'm gonna select Next.

201
00:10:55.823 --> 00:10:57.857
We're at our last step here.

202
00:10:57.857 --> 00:11:01.020
And now this is reviewing everything.

203
00:11:01.020 --> 00:11:04.650
Hey, you're looking to map 11 fields,
zero of them are unmapped.

204
00:11:04.650 --> 00:11:08.127
If we're talking more data, more columns.

205
00:11:08.127 --> 00:11:10.290
And we're gonna start the import.

206
00:11:10.290 --> 00:11:13.748
So, this is letting you know
that import has started.

207
00:11:13.748 --> 00:11:17.905
And it's gonna take you over to the bulk
data load job within Salesforce.

208
00:11:17.905 --> 00:11:21.948
Where you have details to
the operation you're trying to do,

209
00:11:21.948 --> 00:11:23.900
to the start date, end time.

210
00:11:25.040 --> 00:11:26.467
All of these details here.

211
00:11:26.467 --> 00:11:30.516
The operation is we're looking
to insert a new record.

212
00:11:30.516 --> 00:11:32.460
So we can review the results.

213
00:11:33.490 --> 00:11:37.594
And you'll be prompted and you'll
receive an email once it's successful.

214
00:11:37.594 --> 00:11:41.756
And if I scroll down,
what's the records process?

215
00:11:41.756 --> 00:11:42.807
What's the fail count?

216
00:11:42.807 --> 00:11:49.745
What's the retry count on this specific
load and let's view the result.

217
00:11:49.745 --> 00:11:53.685
And you can generate, you can pull that
up but let's go ahead and check and see.

218
00:11:53.685 --> 00:11:55.285
Did that record get created?

219
00:11:55.285 --> 00:11:57.002
So I'm gonna go back, just so

220
00:11:57.002 --> 00:12:00.730
you can see the list of monitoring
these bulk data loading jobs.

221
00:12:00.730 --> 00:12:04.166
And this was an attempt I did earlier,
just to make sure.

222
00:12:04.166 --> 00:12:08.363
And we're gonna see the records so
far that processed.

223
00:12:08.363 --> 00:12:10.827
So we're gonna look into Accounts.

224
00:12:10.827 --> 00:12:14.030
When we're talking one record,
it's gonna be pretty quick but

225
00:12:14.030 --> 00:12:17.065
when you're talking a group of records,
give it some time.

226
00:12:17.065 --> 00:12:21.709
So, let's go hit Go.

227
00:12:21.709 --> 00:12:23.841
And I'm gonna use this up here.

228
00:12:23.841 --> 00:12:24.831
It's helpful.

229
00:12:24.831 --> 00:12:28.782
And we see here the test
account that we created.

230
00:12:28.782 --> 00:12:31.289
And how the fields were pushed in.

231
00:12:31.289 --> 00:12:34.037
And to make sure this was the right one,

232
00:12:34.037 --> 00:12:37.632
I'm gonna look at my created date,
or created by.

233
00:12:37.632 --> 00:12:41.042
And this will show the accountability,
who created this record and at what time.

234
00:12:41.042 --> 00:12:44.958
So when you're working with different
data loaders and pushing in information.

235
00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.365
This field here and last modified field,

236
00:12:47.365 --> 00:12:51.026
these two dates are gonna be
the most useful to check your data.

237
00:12:51.026 --> 00:12:56.280
Or go back in and make changes
to incorrect uploads or upserts.

238
00:12:56.280 --> 00:13:01.816
It's just kind of a way to troubleshoot
any issues that you can come across.

239
00:13:01.816 --> 00:13:03.559
So again we're in Pacific Standard Time.

240
00:13:03.559 --> 00:13:06.896
So this was the import,
this is the changes that were made here.

241
00:13:06.896 --> 00:13:13.422
And you can see how easy it was to
import a record using the data loader.

242
00:13:13.422 --> 00:13:15.840
So let's go back into the home page.

243
00:13:15.840 --> 00:13:18.418
So now you've seen how to upload data.

244
00:13:18.418 --> 00:13:24.570
And you can see from here you can also
at this point mass delete accounts.

245
00:13:24.570 --> 00:13:27.895
And these are existing
accounts within Salesforce and

246
00:13:27.895 --> 00:13:31.952
you can merge these accounts and
transfer accounts at this point.

247
00:13:31.952 --> 00:13:32.632
>> All right, so

248
00:13:32.632 --> 00:13:36.560
pretty cool wizard that allows us to get
that data into the system and Salesforce.

249
00:13:36.560 --> 00:13:39.250
What about trying to get that
data back out if we need it?

250
00:13:39.250 --> 00:13:40.441
>> Great question!

251
00:13:40.441 --> 00:13:42.882
So let's go back into the data management.

252
00:13:42.882 --> 00:13:46.446
So we're going to go to set up,
our quick find.

253
00:13:46.446 --> 00:13:50.175
And let's go to the data management
section within Salesforce so

254
00:13:50.175 --> 00:13:52.560
I'm gonna navigate over to Data Export.

255
00:13:52.560 --> 00:13:55.510
Now this is a great feature
that Salesforce has

256
00:13:55.510 --> 00:13:58.170
because you can have
scheduled exports ran.

257
00:13:58.170 --> 00:14:00.269
And this is something
that you may wanna do or

258
00:14:00.269 --> 00:14:03.234
something I would suggest to
have running in the background.

259
00:14:03.234 --> 00:14:04.729
But there are a few
things to keep in mind.

260
00:14:04.729 --> 00:14:09.659
So if I do not have a current export
already scheduled within this 48

261
00:14:09.659 --> 00:14:13.160
hour time period we can do an export now.

262
00:14:13.160 --> 00:14:16.220
So I'm looking and saying, okay,
you don't have one already scheduled.

263
00:14:16.220 --> 00:14:19.210
So, what's the file type
I'm looking to pull here?

264
00:14:20.220 --> 00:14:22.093
I'm sorry, what's the encoding?

265
00:14:22.093 --> 00:14:26.440
This will do a full back up of your
Salesforce work at this point.

266
00:14:26.440 --> 00:14:30.044
So, if you are looking to capture images,
documents,

267
00:14:30.044 --> 00:14:32.280
files, make sure to select this.

268
00:14:33.670 --> 00:14:38.703
And this field here to include the files
and CRM content and the content versions.

269
00:14:38.703 --> 00:14:42.616
If you're looking for everything,
make sure everything is selected.

270
00:14:42.616 --> 00:14:43.526
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

271
00:14:43.526 --> 00:14:45.017
>> But if you wanna keep it more,

272
00:14:45.017 --> 00:14:48.486
just hey, I wanna do an export of
my accounts and contacts right now.

273
00:14:48.486 --> 00:14:52.931
Then you have the option of which data
do you want to collect, or export out.

274
00:14:52.931 --> 00:14:57.732
So by default include all data,
because this is mostly being used as

275
00:14:57.732 --> 00:15:01.370
a backup of your data,
include all data selected.

276
00:15:01.370 --> 00:15:04.991
But let me see here.

277
00:15:04.991 --> 00:15:07.451
So I think by default it's just
letting you include all data.

278
00:15:07.451 --> 00:15:11.840
[LAUGH] So let's go ahead,
these are your options here.

279
00:15:11.840 --> 00:15:12.596
Okay, here we go.

280
00:15:12.596 --> 00:15:15.639
I was looking to see why
[LAUGH] it would let me select.

281
00:15:15.639 --> 00:15:19.032
So you don't have to deselect
it before selecting as we found.

282
00:15:19.032 --> 00:15:21.835
So you can just select
at this point topics.

283
00:15:21.835 --> 00:15:24.289
I mean it gets real granular,
topics, these are activities.

284
00:15:24.289 --> 00:15:28.596
But most of the time it could just
be contacts, accounts, orders, or

285
00:15:28.596 --> 00:15:32.380
opportunities, or
hey I just wanna do an export of my leads.

286
00:15:32.380 --> 00:15:33.787
So that's the place to do that.

287
00:15:33.787 --> 00:15:35.747
I'm not gonna start the export,

288
00:15:35.747 --> 00:15:38.976
because I wanna show you how
to run scheduled exports.

289
00:15:38.976 --> 00:15:43.380
So you can select the second button
from this page of scheduling an export.

290
00:15:43.380 --> 00:15:48.410
Now, this can be ran same features,
you can do the include all data or

291
00:15:48.410 --> 00:15:51.900
just do an export on certain objects.

292
00:15:51.900 --> 00:15:55.270
But you select the start date and
an end date of this frequency,

293
00:15:55.270 --> 00:15:59.920
and you can select once every month,
twice every month.

294
00:15:59.920 --> 00:16:02.754
You have these filter criteria here.

295
00:16:02.754 --> 00:16:05.271
Is it on the first Sunday of every month,

296
00:16:05.271 --> 00:16:08.764
how often do you wanna have
this running in the backend?

297
00:16:08.764 --> 00:16:11.413
And then again it depends how much
data you have living in here and

298
00:16:11.413 --> 00:16:13.490
how long that's gonna take to pull and
generate.

299
00:16:14.600 --> 00:16:15.940
So, keep that in mind.

300
00:16:15.940 --> 00:16:18.440
I've worked with some orgs and
occurences that

301
00:16:18.440 --> 00:16:22.475
I've gone through where they are looking
to move away into different orgs.

302
00:16:22.475 --> 00:16:25.530
They're looking to go from maybe
a professional edition of Salesforce into

303
00:16:25.530 --> 00:16:26.630
an enterprise edition.

304
00:16:26.630 --> 00:16:28.267
And that's a completely new org.

305
00:16:28.267 --> 00:16:32.986
So we need to collect all the data from
their Salesforce Professional edition.

306
00:16:32.986 --> 00:16:38.346
Export that out and push into
an enterprise Salesforce [INAUDIBLE].

307
00:16:38.346 --> 00:16:40.741
And make sure everything maps and aligns.

308
00:16:40.741 --> 00:16:44.409
Now in that scenario if they have
these exports already running and

309
00:16:44.409 --> 00:16:46.860
we're looking to do it today.

310
00:16:46.860 --> 00:16:51.280
You, one, either need to log a case
with Salesforce and have them do it.

311
00:16:51.280 --> 00:16:54.688
Otherwise, we have to stop this export and
wait for

312
00:16:54.688 --> 00:16:59.377
that to complete before we can run and
generate the Export Now option.

313
00:16:59.377 --> 00:17:02.865
And in that case, you need to
make sure everything's selected.

314
00:17:02.865 --> 00:17:07.380
If you're looking at pushing all content
and data into a completely new org.

315
00:17:08.952 --> 00:17:09.650
>> All right Felicia,

316
00:17:09.650 --> 00:17:13.030
again, another great look there at some of
the things we can do inside Salesforce.

317
00:17:13.030 --> 00:17:16.200
Here we were looking at how we
can get data into Salesforce, so

318
00:17:16.200 --> 00:17:17.990
different import and loader methods.

319
00:17:17.990 --> 00:17:19.977
We also looked at how we can get data out.

320
00:17:19.977 --> 00:17:23.523
If we need to maybe work with
that data in another application.

321
00:17:23.523 --> 00:17:26.523
Or simply to make sure we've got
a good backup of that data or

322
00:17:26.523 --> 00:17:28.850
if we're moving from one org to another.

323
00:17:28.850 --> 00:17:29.760
So we thank you for that.

324
00:17:29.760 --> 00:17:31.270
Great demonstrations there.

325
00:17:31.270 --> 00:17:33.910
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

326
00:17:33.910 --> 00:17:35.140
Signing off for ITPRO.TV.

327
00:17:35.140 --> 00:17:37.230
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

328
00:17:37.230 --> 00:17:37.995
>> I'm Felicia Duarte.

329
00:17:37.995 --> 00:17:40.097
>> And we'll see you next time.

330
00:17:40.097 --> 00:17:46.035
[MUSIC]

331
00:17:46.035 --> 00:17:49.294
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Felicia and Mike cover reporting in Salesforce. They look at the different types of reports and report formats. They also demonstrate creating a dashboard.
episodes.title: Analytics, Reports and Dashboards
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.566
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.566 --> 00:00:06.394
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.394 --> 00:00:08.863
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.863 --> 00:00:10.719
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.719 --> 00:00:15.256
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.256 --> 00:00:17.018
I'm your host Mike Rodrick,

7
00:00:17.018 --> 00:00:21.600
and today we're doing our
Salesforce Certified Administrator.

8
00:00:21.600 --> 00:00:25.347
In this episode, we're gonna take
a look at how we can use reports and

9
00:00:25.347 --> 00:00:27.168
dashboards to analyze our data.

10
00:00:27.168 --> 00:00:30.240
And here to help us with
that is Miss Felicia Duarte.

11
00:00:30.240 --> 00:00:31.180
Welcome back Felicia.

12
00:00:31.180 --> 00:00:32.380
>> Great, thank you.

13
00:00:32.380 --> 00:00:35.160
So, in this episode we're
gonna cover reports.

14
00:00:35.160 --> 00:00:38.185
Let's start out with
the report properties.

15
00:00:38.185 --> 00:00:40.505
What are the different types of reports?

16
00:00:40.505 --> 00:00:44.925
We're also gonna cover dashboards, how
to link reports and dashboards together.

17
00:00:44.925 --> 00:00:48.945
What type of data and reports can I
run that are standard from Salesforce?

18
00:00:48.945 --> 00:00:51.866
And what are some custom report
types that I can create?

19
00:00:51.866 --> 00:00:57.454
So to start, I'm gonna hop right
in into the reports object and

20
00:00:57.454 --> 00:01:00.203
start with creating a report.

21
00:01:00.203 --> 00:01:02.480
So we're gonna navigate over here.

22
00:01:04.220 --> 00:01:06.230
And to start,
we're at the report home page.

23
00:01:06.230 --> 00:01:10.230
So this object looks different than any
other object that you see in Salesforce.

24
00:01:10.230 --> 00:01:12.290
So to your left, you have your folders.

25
00:01:12.290 --> 00:01:14.600
Now, when you create a report,
which you'll see,

26
00:01:14.600 --> 00:01:18.700
you have to select from which object
am I creating this report from.

27
00:01:18.700 --> 00:01:22.600
Is it my account and contacts,
my leads, my opportunities?

28
00:01:22.600 --> 00:01:27.170
Or if it's a custom object,
you wanna do a custom report type.

29
00:01:27.170 --> 00:01:28.765
But, as you're building an object,

30
00:01:28.765 --> 00:01:32.816
it'll add it's own other folder,
which we'll get into.

31
00:01:32.816 --> 00:01:36.226
Just coming out straight from Salesforce,
you can see that it breaks it up and

32
00:01:36.226 --> 00:01:38.100
gives you a lot of great useful reports.

33
00:01:38.100 --> 00:01:39.874
So it gives you from opportunity reports.

34
00:01:39.874 --> 00:01:43.573
It'll automatically create
a closed opportunities,

35
00:01:43.573 --> 00:01:47.610
contact role reports,
forecasting, your pipeline.

36
00:01:47.610 --> 00:01:50.861
So being acquainted with what
Salesforce gives you is great.

37
00:01:50.861 --> 00:01:54.820
As admin, to start at the box so
you're not duplicating your work.

38
00:01:54.820 --> 00:01:58.110
Or, even greater,
use what they give you as a baseline, and

39
00:01:58.110 --> 00:02:00.200
then make customizations from there.

40
00:02:00.200 --> 00:02:04.742
Clone the report, save as the report,
rather than building from scratch.

41
00:02:04.742 --> 00:02:09.251
And this is also the same
place where dashboards live.

42
00:02:09.251 --> 00:02:13.756
And the creation, or the place to create a
dashboard, is all held in the same place.

43
00:02:13.756 --> 00:02:18.302
So new reports and new dashboards,

So those are your options there for
reporting.

272
00:15:46.929 --> 00:15:52.077
Now Dashboards, a dashboard is,
let's get into one first,

273
00:15:52.077 --> 00:15:57.324
to show you is a live representation
of your up to 20 reports,

274
00:15:57.324 --> 00:16:05.378
so when we select New Dashboard I'm
gonna select, Show Me Later.

275
00:16:05.378 --> 00:16:08.940
So you can pull in up to
20 reports onto this field.

276
00:16:08.940 --> 00:16:11.680
And there's a drag and drop interface too.

277
00:16:11.680 --> 00:16:13.580
So we're gonna select, Data Sources.

278
00:16:13.580 --> 00:16:19.650
Cuz we don't have component, cuz we don't
have a source to drag a component onto.

279
00:16:19.650 --> 00:16:21.250
So I'm gonna select my data source.

280
00:16:22.720 --> 00:16:25.680
And I'm gonna select, Reports.

281
00:16:25.680 --> 00:16:27.790
And I'm looking for the file and
this is the one we just created.

282
00:16:27.790 --> 00:16:30.019
So I'm gonna drag and drop that over here.

283
00:16:30.019 --> 00:16:33.842
Now, when you start moving over 10s, 15,

284
00:16:33.842 --> 00:16:40.000
20 reports into this in order for
it to save, it has to have a component.

285
00:16:40.000 --> 00:16:41.680
Now if we've already pre-built these out,

286
00:16:41.680 --> 00:16:45.220
we've already added a chart to
the report like we did previously.

287
00:16:45.220 --> 00:16:48.330
It's kind of tedious to do it again and
do all the set up.

288
00:16:48.330 --> 00:16:53.350
So if you select the wrench, rather than
having to redo it at the report level,

289
00:16:53.350 --> 00:16:56.030
just select Use Chart as
Defined in the Source Report,

290
00:16:56.030 --> 00:16:58.550
and it's gonna pull it from the report,
itself.

291
00:16:58.550 --> 00:17:00.450
And this is what we created.

292
00:17:00.450 --> 00:17:03.220
So when you're looking at
a dashboard of 20 different reports,

293
00:17:03.220 --> 00:17:05.520
you wanna have a title.

294
00:17:05.520 --> 00:17:06.630
You can have a header.

295
00:17:06.630 --> 00:17:11.855
And so
let's just name this active accounts.

296
00:17:11.855 --> 00:17:16.015
And so you can play with what Salesforce
gives you here, what's the source.

297
00:17:16.015 --> 00:17:18.355
And then, the dashboard properties.

298
00:17:18.355 --> 00:17:22.485
So you can have what's called
a dynamic dashboard and Salesforce.

299
00:17:22.485 --> 00:17:24.281
And this is something
I do see on the quiz.

300
00:17:24.281 --> 00:17:26.365
What does a dynamic dashboard do?

301
00:17:26.365 --> 00:17:31.290
That can make it tailored to, right now
we're looking at active accounts for

302
00:17:31.290 --> 00:17:35.152
everyone but when you want a user
to be logged in as herself and

303
00:17:35.152 --> 00:17:40.459
only see information that's relevant to
them whether they're active accounts,

304
00:17:40.459 --> 00:17:45.510
what is that user's active
opportunities or closed opportunities?

305
00:17:45.510 --> 00:17:47.350
Now for the org as a whole, but

306
00:17:47.350 --> 00:17:50.460
as an individual, you wanna create
what's called the Dynamic Dashboard.

307
00:17:50.460 --> 00:17:52.928
So your dashboard has to have a title.

308
00:17:56.328 --> 00:18:00.216
And in my personal dashboard,
and went over the settings here,

309
00:18:00.216 --> 00:18:02.430
component settings.

310
00:18:02.430 --> 00:18:06.380
So, we're gonna hit OK, and
now we have this saved.

311
00:18:06.380 --> 00:18:10.200
We have the dashboard properties saved,
the components in here, the fields.

312
00:18:10.200 --> 00:18:12.740
And who are we viewing this dashboard as?

313
00:18:12.740 --> 00:18:14.280
Right now myself.

314
00:18:14.280 --> 00:18:18.150
So if we wanted to make this dynamic,
go to the far right and

315
00:18:18.150 --> 00:18:21.100
select Run As Locked In Users.

316
00:18:21.100 --> 00:18:26.070
If you want to give them the authorization
to change the running user, you can.

317
00:18:26.070 --> 00:18:28.730
But, if not, just select OK.

318
00:18:28.730 --> 00:18:33.539
And then the details and the reports that
show up here that you've already built

319
00:18:33.539 --> 00:18:35.635
will run based off the login user.

320
00:18:37.797 --> 00:18:41.048
So to navigate back to your homepage,
we went through reports,

321
00:18:41.048 --> 00:18:44.483
what you can do with the report,
what you can do with the dashboard,

322
00:18:44.483 --> 00:18:47.250
how to build off those visual charts.

323
00:18:47.250 --> 00:18:51.180
Another topic I want to go into is,
we've gone through folder management.

324
00:18:51.180 --> 00:18:55.040
But some other types of content you
can have within Salesforce course.

325
00:18:55.040 --> 00:18:58.160
So this covers for
a small percentage within the,

326
00:18:58.160 --> 00:19:04.740
so we're going to surf for
content within the exam itself.

327
00:19:04.740 --> 00:19:07.430
So within Salesforce you have
whats called content deliveries.

328
00:19:07.430 --> 00:19:11.200
So you can have a file
stored within Salesforce.

329
00:19:11.200 --> 00:19:15.210
You know PDF files stored as
attachments within records, but

330
00:19:15.210 --> 00:19:18.220
they need to be
Microsoft Word PowerPoints, but

331
00:19:18.220 --> 00:19:22.640
they need to be stored in a certain
format as you're sending out emails.

332
00:19:22.640 --> 00:19:25.750
So this is something that you can
enable for content deliveries.

333
00:19:25.750 --> 00:19:27.890
Whether you want password protection.

334
00:19:27.890 --> 00:19:29.750
If it's something that
should be optional or

335
00:19:29.750 --> 00:19:31.880
if there should be a default setting here.

336
00:19:31.880 --> 00:19:35.580
So these are just changes that you
can make as you're sending out, and

337
00:19:35.580 --> 00:19:38.830
you're sending out more secure
information via the web.

338
00:19:38.830 --> 00:19:41.510
So, that's content deliveries, and

339
00:19:41.510 --> 00:19:45.570
then another piece that I want
to go over would be tags.

340
00:19:45.570 --> 00:19:51.200
So, within Salesforce or orgs that
are moving away from other system.

341
00:19:51.200 --> 00:19:56.140
I see a lot of requests for,
hey I have tags within my other system and

342
00:19:56.140 --> 00:19:58.410
what does that look like in Salesforce or
you know,

343
00:19:58.410 --> 00:20:01.780
I run my whole entire business off tags,
what do I do now?

344
00:20:01.780 --> 00:20:04.930
So as an alternative you
create those fields and

345
00:20:04.930 --> 00:20:09.680
you start generating these reports
to kind of work with those tags.

346
00:20:09.680 --> 00:20:14.660
So if it was, the tag was sent
sample from the other database

347
00:20:14.660 --> 00:20:18.431
you can see a list of all accounts that
you sent the sample to but instead,

348
00:20:18.431 --> 00:20:23.080
in Salesforce you would have
an opportunity with maybe a check box

349
00:20:23.080 --> 00:20:27.640
sent that said sample, and a report
that you create that generates a list of

350
00:20:27.640 --> 00:20:31.500
all accounts you've sent samples
to in a given time period.

351
00:20:31.500 --> 00:20:35.470
That's jut an example of how you're
moving away from one system to the next,

352
00:20:35.470 --> 00:20:40.500
from tags related to custom
fields in a report instead.

353
00:20:40.500 --> 00:20:45.430
But if you do still wanna enable tags you
can, but sometimes I've seen orgs where

354
00:20:45.430 --> 00:20:50.970
they just have one too many where it's
probably better to utilize a custom field.

355
00:20:50.970 --> 00:20:55.490
So this is something you have to enable,
so I'm gonna go over to Tag Settings.

356
00:20:57.490 --> 00:21:02.780
And I wanna give it a sec and
I enable personal tags.

357
00:21:02.780 --> 00:21:06.820
And you see here you have the option of
where you want it enable personal tag,

358
00:21:06.820 --> 00:21:09.568
it is reports, documents,
notes, dashboards,

359
00:21:09.568 --> 00:21:14.480
what layouts and these are available.

360
00:21:14.480 --> 00:21:18.530
I'm just gonna pull it all in and we
created a property custom object earlier

361
00:21:18.530 --> 00:21:21.080
so all your custom objects
have that same option.

362
00:21:21.080 --> 00:21:22.900
And I'm gonna hit Save.

363
00:21:24.950 --> 00:21:27.040
And now we can go into accounts.

364
00:21:32.040 --> 00:21:34.710
And you'll be able to have
the option as you bring it through,

365
00:21:34.710 --> 00:21:37.210
adding different tags here, users.

366
00:21:37.210 --> 00:21:38.860
I'm sorry, to the records itself.

367
00:21:38.860 --> 00:21:41.540
And being able to kind of
sort through those tags here.

368
00:21:41.540 --> 00:21:45.050
So at the very top,
right above your feed, and this is for

369
00:21:45.050 --> 00:21:47.850
any record you can add a tag.

370
00:21:47.850 --> 00:21:49.750
Prospect, Save.

371
00:21:49.750 --> 00:21:53.260
And you can do the comma.

372
00:21:53.260 --> 00:21:56.360
Now you'll see it's saved under here.

373
00:21:56.360 --> 00:22:01.360
Separate from a list view, you can go
in and remove the records from those

374
00:22:01.360 --> 00:22:07.520
certain tags, and so that's to show you
how to enable tags within Salesforce.

375
00:22:07.520 --> 00:22:10.930
>> All right Felicia, again another great
look at what we can do with Salesforce.

376
00:22:10.930 --> 00:22:14.930
In this case really taking a look at
how we can use the analytics built into

377
00:22:14.930 --> 00:22:19.010
Salesforce to really work with and
manipulate and view our data.

378
00:22:19.010 --> 00:22:22.710
And wow, how about creating those reports,
no formulas to create.

379
00:22:22.710 --> 00:22:24.380
I mean you can if you want, right?

380
00:22:24.380 --> 00:22:27.860
But you can also do drag and drop and
it calculates everything for you.

381
00:22:27.860 --> 00:22:30.170
Grouping summaries, fantastic stuff.

382
00:22:30.170 --> 00:22:33.850
So we hope everybody out there
appreciated this one and enjoyed it.

383
00:22:33.850 --> 00:22:37.360
For now signing off for IT Pro TV I've
been your host Mike Rodrick.

384
00:22:37.360 --> 00:22:38.340
>> And I'm Felicia Doherty.

385
00:22:38.340 --> 00:22:40.189
>> And we'll see you next time.

386
00:22:40.189 --> 00:22:46.215
[MUSIC]

387
00:22:46.215 --> 00:22:51.799
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Felicia and Mike demonstrate creating workflows in Salesforce. They look at how workflows can be used to update fields, create tasks, and send messages. They also discuss the approval process.
episodes.title: Workflow Automation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:03.742
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:03.742 --> 00:00:08.248
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.248 --> 00:00:11.864
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.864 --> 00:00:15.380
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.380 --> 00:00:17.360
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:17.360 --> 00:00:20.180
Today we're doing our
Salesforce Certified Administrator.

7
00:00:20.180 --> 00:00:24.230
And in this episode we're gonna be
taking a look at how we can do workflow

8
00:00:24.230 --> 00:00:25.120
automation.

9
00:00:25.120 --> 00:00:27.930
And here to help us with that,
is Miss Felicia Duarte.

10
00:00:27.930 --> 00:00:29.114
Welcome back, Felicia.

11
00:00:29.114 --> 00:00:30.282
>> Great, thank you.

12
00:00:30.282 --> 00:00:34.030
So, I'm gonna cover one of my
favorite topics, workflow automation.

13
00:00:34.030 --> 00:00:39.450
So, this accounts for 9% of questions
within the sales force exam.

14
00:00:39.450 --> 00:00:43.030
So, what is the workflow,
what can I do, what's covered.

15
00:00:44.090 --> 00:00:47.450
Everyone's aware that there's a new
process called the process builder.

16
00:00:47.450 --> 00:00:50.540
As of today,
that's not included in the exam itself so

17
00:00:50.540 --> 00:00:52.880
we're just gonna cover
workflow automation.

18
00:00:52.880 --> 00:00:57.795
What kind of workflow do, what are some
kind of workflows, what are the criterias?

19
00:00:57.795 --> 00:01:02.015
And go through a demo of
creating one ourselves.

20
00:01:02.015 --> 00:01:05.234
So, I'm gonna jump in and
give some examples of different types and

21
00:01:05.234 --> 00:01:08.095
what you can do with the workflow
from the setup options.

22
00:01:08.095 --> 00:01:14.535
So, for one a workflow you can do
you can create, do a field update.

23
00:01:14.535 --> 00:01:18.020
So, let me log into the workflow
itself I'm going to workflow rules.

24
00:01:20.440 --> 00:01:23.130
And another goal that I like to mention,
is we'll also go through approvals.

25
00:01:23.130 --> 00:01:25.460
So, we're gonna discuss workflows and
approvals.

26
00:01:25.460 --> 00:01:27.240
So, what can a workflow do?

27
00:01:27.240 --> 00:01:31.400
You can create a task,
update a field, send an email, or

28
00:01:31.400 --> 00:01:36.180
send an outbound message based off
the criteria that you give it.

29
00:01:36.180 --> 00:01:39.250
So, this is one of the neat features
that Salesforce has in making

30
00:01:39.250 --> 00:01:41.420
most of your business process, automated.

31
00:01:41.420 --> 00:01:45.060
And you can make it as automated
as you want with workflow rules,

32
00:01:45.060 --> 00:01:48.000
based off this criteria
without jumping into code.

33
00:01:48.000 --> 00:01:49.720
So with clicks not code.

34
00:01:49.720 --> 00:01:51.086
So, we're gonna go through and

35
00:01:51.086 --> 00:01:54.131
here's some examples that Salesforce
gives you from the homepage.

36
00:01:54.131 --> 00:01:57.690
You can opt out not to see it again,
what's you get comfortable.

37
00:01:57.690 --> 00:02:02.100
But, if you're still kind of learning
it this is great to have as a start.

38
00:02:02.100 --> 00:02:04.850
So, I'm gonna hit continue.

39
00:02:04.850 --> 00:02:08.860
And now, right now, this will show
a list of all your workflow rules.

40
00:02:08.860 --> 00:02:12.010
I've had to set up for
org 75 workflow rules before.

41
00:02:12.010 --> 00:02:14.290
So, you really want to make
sure you're descriptive.

42
00:02:14.290 --> 00:02:17.660
I can't express enough how descriptive
you are with your workflow rules.

43
00:02:17.660 --> 00:02:19.040
Because as you're trying to go through and

44
00:02:19.040 --> 00:02:23.070
troubleshoot workflow rules
that aren't working or that.

45
00:02:23.070 --> 00:02:26.980
Are inactive or you need to see what we're
closer encountering against each other,

46
00:02:26.980 --> 00:02:31.110
you wanna be able to define with
its description what it is doing,

47
00:02:31.110 --> 00:02:33.320
what's the criteria.

48
00:02:33.320 --> 00:02:36.950
So right here, Salesforce will not
give you any workflows out the back,

49
00:02:36.950 --> 00:02:40.900
out the blocks, so
to automate this process more,

50
00:02:40.900 --> 00:02:43.400
you wanna go into the workflow section.

51
00:02:43.400 --> 00:02:48.480
Now, I created this one as an example,
just to show you but it is inactive.

52
00:02:48.480 --> 00:02:51.140
So, when you go to create a new rule.

53
00:02:51.140 --> 00:02:53.990
We'll use that one as an example
walk through it together.

54
00:02:53.990 --> 00:02:56.930
You have to select the object
from what you're working from.

55
00:02:56.930 --> 00:03:00.820
So, we'll use opportunities as an example.

56
00:03:00.820 --> 00:03:04.730
Some common ones are maybe I wanna
reach out to my contacts, or

57
00:03:04.730 --> 00:03:07.920
send them a birthday email
every time it's their birthday.

58
00:03:07.920 --> 00:03:10.505
You first need to make
sure that field exists.

59
00:03:10.505 --> 00:03:13.580
You need to make sure
it's in the right format.

60
00:03:13.580 --> 00:03:18.780
So, opportunities a common one they
see is changing the opportunity name.

61
00:03:18.780 --> 00:03:22.360
So, if there is a certain default
criteria that you want your

62
00:03:22.360 --> 00:03:23.690
opportunity to look like.

63
00:03:23.690 --> 00:03:28.100
Maybe it's the opportunity
plus an auto number or

64
00:03:28.100 --> 00:03:30.910
plus something that, a product field.

65
00:03:30.910 --> 00:03:36.450
You kinda set that, set that up for
your clients and make things automated.

66
00:03:36.450 --> 00:03:39.520
And you can also place
your contacts in certain

67
00:03:39.520 --> 00:03:41.800
buckets if they are orphan contacts.

68
00:03:41.800 --> 00:03:43.990
Like an individual account record.

69
00:03:43.990 --> 00:03:46.020
But we're gonna start,
we have to give it a rule name.

70
00:03:46.020 --> 00:03:48.160
So, what is this rule name?

71
00:03:48.160 --> 00:03:50.580
Using one of my examples,
I'm going to go with opportunity name.

72
00:03:52.530 --> 00:03:54.530
When an opportunity is created.

73
00:03:56.062 --> 00:04:01.542
Update, The opportunity name.

74
00:04:03.873 --> 00:04:06.480
So, evaluation criteria.

75
00:04:06.480 --> 00:04:08.740
When do you want this
rule to be evaluated?

76
00:04:08.740 --> 00:04:11.680
Is it only at the point that
this record is created?

77
00:04:11.680 --> 00:04:17.334
Because if you select created it will only
evaluate it at that point that the records

78
00:04:17.334 --> 00:04:23.012
have been created, whether its through an
import or a manual creation of a record.

79
00:04:23.012 --> 00:04:27.461
But if and so when we look at it again if
it's edited, but if you wanna look at it

80
00:04:27.461 --> 00:04:32.185
every single time it's edited, you'll
select a middle one, and with this one,

81
00:04:32.185 --> 00:04:35.960
you can add time dependent
workflow actions with this option.

82
00:04:35.960 --> 00:04:41.780
But, if you wanna to be only evaluated
every time it meets the criteria,

83
00:04:41.780 --> 00:04:43.410
then you select the last one.

84
00:04:43.410 --> 00:04:46.570
Right now, we're gonna go with this
one that every time it's edited,

85
00:04:46.570 --> 00:04:48.690
I want the recorded to be evaluated.

86
00:04:50.020 --> 00:04:52.430
In this example,
usually I go with this one, but

87
00:04:52.430 --> 00:04:56.320
in this example its only gonna look at
it when the opportunity is created.

88
00:04:56.320 --> 00:04:58.690
So, this maybe the better fit here.

89
00:04:58.690 --> 00:05:02.909
But test out your workflows, I can't
stress this enough if you're working with

90
00:05:02.909 --> 00:05:06.045
an existing environment,
work in a sandbox environment.

91
00:05:06.045 --> 00:05:10.523
Because when you're doing email
alerts with existing data,

92
00:05:10.523 --> 00:05:15.531
you're affecting your users and
you're affecting your contacts.

93
00:05:15.531 --> 00:05:17.935
And you don't wanna work
in a live environment.

94
00:05:17.935 --> 00:05:19.685
So, what's your criteria?

95
00:05:19.685 --> 00:05:23.105
So, is this run this rule if
the following criteria is met or

96
00:05:23.105 --> 00:05:25.455
if it's a formula to
evaluate it to be true?

97
00:05:25.455 --> 00:05:29.070
So, right now, let's just with
the created date, keep it real simple.

98
00:05:30.830 --> 00:05:35.370
So, created date,
I'm gonna use greater than or equal to,

99
00:05:35.370 --> 00:05:37.910
and just use a real
simple formula of today.

100
00:05:39.150 --> 00:05:40.560
And you can do date ranges,

101
00:05:40.560 --> 00:05:43.740
you can go based off any field
you have in sales force.

102
00:05:44.930 --> 00:05:50.740
So, I'm gonna hit save and next, And
another thing I didn't touch base on,

103
00:05:50.740 --> 00:05:54.750
I'm gonna take a step back as I saw
as I was saving, is the filter logic.

104
00:05:54.750 --> 00:05:58.480
So, if you added more criteria
onto the filter logic and

105
00:05:58.480 --> 00:06:00.082
you needed to have in this example.

106
00:06:00.082 --> 00:06:05.249
I wanna do in a filter based off, the
amount that's greater than a million and

107
00:06:05.249 --> 00:06:10.178
the close date is equal to next 45 days
and the owner role starts with VP,

108
00:06:10.178 --> 00:06:12.104
then you can select, is it.

109
00:06:12.104 --> 00:06:15.586
It has to be the amount greater
than with that 1 million and

110
00:06:15.586 --> 00:06:19.020
the close it has to be
over the next 45 days.

111
